summary: In 1987, Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio) takes an entry-level job at a Wall Street brokerage firm. By the early 1990s, while still in his 20s, Belfort founds his own firm, Stratton Oakmont. Together with his trusted lieutenant (Jonah Hill) and a merry band of brokers, Belfort makes a huge fortune by defrauding wealthy investors out of millions. However, while Belfort and his cronies partake in a hedonistic brew of sex, drugs and thrills, the SEC and the FBI close in on his empire of excess.

reviews.content:
The film, directed by Martin Scorsese and starring Leonardo DiCaprio, was a thrilling portrayal of the wild and debaucherous life of Jordan Belfort, a stockbroker who rose to fame in the 1990s.

DiCaprio's performance was outstanding - he truly embodied the persona of Belfort, making him both charismatic and despicable at the same time. The supporting cast, including Jonah Hill and Margot Robbie, were also fantastic, bringing depth and nuance to their roles.

The film's pacing was excellent, with a perfect balance of drama, humor, and action. The cinematography was also stunning, with beautiful shots of New York City and other locations. The soundtrack was also excellent, featuring a range of music that perfectly matched the tone of each scene.
I am massively dissapointed. There were no wolves or walls there was just a man high on cocaine for 90 minutes. This is the worst animal documentary ive ever watched

Jordan is literally me

The movie was pretty poor quality which I wouldn't expect from Leo, but there was one actor that made me down rate it.  There was a fat ginger guy that just took me out of the movie, I saw him and knew that this wasn't a serious film.

DiCaprio truly elevated the crappy guy into an amazing character. The characters around him are also great, Jonah Hill's character being another standout.

It got to a point where there was just so much sex and nudity that didn't serve the story. Other than that it's a really great movie and I thoroughly  enjoyed it!

I can't stop laughing whenever I watch this movie. Each little 5 minute scene is a gem. This is the film you get when you bring together the best writers, director, actors, extras, camera people (ok - cinematographers lo) and just let loose. Let the actors go over the top. Rob Reiner gives it the full jewish schtick, like a parody of overachievers. DiCaprio gives everything he's got. And that's a lot. His scene with the Lambo and the Ludes with his friend take things to a new level of craziness. And Scorsese makes sure that every expression by the actors, every drunken fall, every lustful look
 is captured. This movie is what makes Hollywood the world capital of entertainment. So, why only 4 stars? Because I save 5 stars for Citizen Kane.

A triumphantly brilliant work from a genius Martin Scorsese, Wolf of Wall Street is an egotistical, raving, and above all hilarious work from one of the greatest directors of all time, not to mention a stellar cast with Leonardo DiCaprio, Margot Robbie, and Jonah Hill.
great. just great. margot robbie is fit
Awful; just senseless debauchery. Watch to laugh at and pity some rich fools.

3 hours of pure awesomeness. Every scene is entertaining, which is something I don't think I can say about any other movie. Usually with longer films, you'll feel the runtime eventually. But this movie was so fast-paced that it didn't even feel two hours long. And I'd be remiss not to mention Leo's incredible performance. He was truly robbed of the Oscar.

The plot of "The Wolf of Wall Street" was very interesting. It has a very unique plot unlike most movie or book plots, it felt very original.This movie is based on a true story and it shares the life story of a business CEO, Jordan Belfort, who ran a large company on Wall Street in the 90s and early 2000s. He used stock tactics to con people out of money while making millions for himself. I thought there were a lot of different things that happened to keep the viewer entertained, it was a comedy and with jokes for all ages. I felt that the timeline of this movie was also very organized, it wasn't confusing or hard to follow along with the story. 
 One of the main focuses in the movie was Jordan Befort's addiction to drugs. I thought the movie did a nice job of showing how drugs really ruin your life. It didn't over glorify drugs which a lot of movies do and it left you with a nice and important message.
The ending of this movie was pretty intense but it did wrap up everything nicely, there weren't a lot of lingering questions.The ending was also realistic, not everything works out perfectly. If you are someone who likes very happy endings this movie might not be the best for you but on the other hand if you're someone who likes realistic endings you will probably really enjoy this movie. 
All the actors in this movie did a really nice job acting. They all really embodied their characters. I felt like each character seemed real, it didn't feel like actors were just playing a role. Margot Robbie did a good job making me really believe her character was a real person and that she was a loving wife. They all were able to demonstrate multiple sides to their characters and portray a lot of different emotions within them which can be very hard for an actor to do. I thought Leonardo Dicaprio did the best job at this while playing Jordan Befort. He was able to convince me that he was actually high during his drug scenes and was able to convince me he was actually crazy during some of his other scenes. 
I felt the script was really good. The script was written with a satire element to bring the story to life to explain how the events felt from the perspective of the main character. There weren't really any scenes that stood out as being cringy, but there were a lot of scenes that were unrealistic in a satire way.
This is a very long movie so if you're someone who has a short attention span it might be hard to stay engaged. I felt the middle of this movie had a lot of scenes that developed the story line and kept the watcher engaged. There were many scenes that explained the work life and the home life of the main character, Jordan Belfort, which helps the viewer get more insight into his experiences and what Wall Street was like.
Overwrought and not sure DiCaprio was right for the part.
Very funny, I saw this like 3 times and never got tired of it.
A brilliant mocumentary about the true wolf of Wall Street.

I can't recommend it.  To be fair, this movie is well-acted, sleek, fun to look at, and has some entertaining lines in it.  Margot Robbie, as the hottest woman in the world, does not disappoint.  DiCaprio is great at always.

But the message really is sickening, and gratuitously so in a way that it didn't have to be.  The 2 hours of rich criminals gorging the best drugs, hookers, yachts and mansions is all par for the course, but there's never a sense of any of it being destructive, immoral or having any real consequences.  In truth, tons of real people got conned and lost their life savings, and their story isn't even hinted about.  

There was never going to be any proper comeuppance for the amount of luxury Belfort grifted his way to for a decade, but "3 years playing tennis in a country club prison and then a speaking tour" is a slap in the face, and then showing the real Jordan Belfort partying it up with DiCaprio is a bigger slap in the face.  And it's all done with a wink to the audience and with engaging jokes and infectious mania, as though this character is really just a lovable "boys will be boys" scamp.  Rather than it being a cautionary tale about literally anything, it screams through the screen "Just be as greedy, Narcissistic, abusive and hedonistic as you want, and even when it all falls apart, m'eh, it's a slap on the wrist for you while every one of your victims suffers in silent irrelevance.

I am not against movies where everything is unfairly tilted toward the heroes, but usually those heroes are either fighters that painstakingly earn such a victory, class clowns that the audience can live vicariously through the dumb luck of, or ordinary people who deserve some positivity in their lives.  This movie takes a drug-addled criminal psychopath, enables him throughout, whitewashes his image and then begs the audience to associate his greed with endlessly perfect breasts and chemical highs and applause.  Even in A Clockwork Orange, the villains got a better lesson than this.
Awful movie, even worse acting by Margot Robbie
Hilarious, dramatic, and real. This movie was fantastic and however long kept me laughing and invested throughout its entirety. One of the best since the turn of the century. Simply fantastic
Fun, edgy, entertaining.

Probably Martin Scorsese's most free-wheeling and uninhibited movie, The Wolf of Wall Street is the story of Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio) who, after losing his prestigious and well-paid job on Wall Street, establishes his own business dealing in shady penny stocks, ultimately leading him to a life of unimaginable wealth…and equally unimaginable legal issues.  DiCaprio is great in the lead role, as are Jonah Hill as his drug-addled friend and business associate Donnie Azoff and Margot Robbie as Jordan's exasperated wife.  Other than some of the worst continuity that you'll ever see in a major, big-budget film, there isn't much to dislike about The Wolf of Wall Street, unless you are offended by excessive drug use, midget tossing, vulgar language, and plenty of sex, all of which seem to be part of the game when dealing with characters of this nature.
best movie of all time
Silly man climbs his way to superberfullness - Light 8/10
Another Scorsese classic. Amazing soundtrack. Amazing story. Really enjoyed this movie and consider this a timeless movie. Dicaprio was great as always too.

If you don't like these types of movies then The Wolf of Wall Street will be your least favorite film of all time. For all other people, The Wolf of Wall Street is funny, has plenty of dark humour and variative content with a magical screenplay that is the helm of Martin Scorsese who nails it yet again with a DiCaprio performance that might be one of his most commited to date.

Great acting in the movie and was cool throughout, I believe it was extended a bit too long at some times though.
You'll be exhausted by this excess three hours story about a silly rich man. This is a warning. Stars for DiCaprio's performance.

A (not-so)cautionary tale of financial & hedonistic extravaganza dressed in a thousand dollar suit and a golden smile. Scorsese does it again and this time with the superfluous DiCaprio, this is one to be watched time and time again.

It's as well-structured as you'd expect from a Scorsese film.  And yet the endless greed, scamming and debauchery portrayed here becomes wearying, especially considering coming as it did shortly after the Great Recession, caused largely by scammers and get-rich-quick parasites like Jordan Belfort portrayed here.  Watching this movie seems a slap in the face to anyone who lost a job or a home during those tough years, and to see Belfort elevated to something of a hero here is just maddening.  Perhaps you will disagree, and feel that art should be evaluated on its own terms, separate from place and time it was made; if so, this review isn't for you.

I finally was able to watch this Martin Scorsese classic. This is Martin Scorsese's best movie and not only that, it's Leonardo Di Caprio's best acting performance. An entertaining watch from beginning to end thanks to the loaded cast. Martin Scorsese's directing and writing is just so good. The movie is very well shot with fantastic cinematography. It does a great job at balancing humor while telling the depressing story of Jordan Belfort. Leonardo Di Caprio, Margot Robbie, Jonah Hill, Jon Bernthal, Matthew McConaughey, and the rest of the cast give tremendous performances. Overall, despite all of the negative things people say about people loving this movie, this genuinely is one of the best movies I've ever watch.

It really shines the problem with greed and money overtaking a person's life. It shows a great character change with Leonardo Dicaprio being an innocent young worker in Wallstreet to the real wolf at the end. Great film. 9/10.

Yet again, watching this, the 3 hour runtime just flies by. It's endlessly entertaining. You want to hate DiCaprio's character for being such a scumbag, but he's just soo engaging, and Scorsese presents him with soo much flash, that you can't help but get wrapped up and drawn into his world.

For a movie that was almost three hours, it flew by and was incredibly engaging. I can not believe it took me this long to see it.

Score: 90%
Verdict: Excellent
Most quotable movie for me

The Wolf of Wall Street is an all downhill rollercoaster ride through a mind saddled with insatiable greed and an, often hilarious, illustration of the pitfalls and perils that result from the overindulgence that accompanies it.

These absolutely awful characters are written and portrayed so perfectly that I almost feel guilt free enjoying some of them as much as I do. DiCaprio is on fire and yet somehow is surpassed by Jonah Hill, who easily earns my MVP on this watch. Margot Robbie was much better than I remember as well and is still towards the top of my list of top bets for a future best actress statue.

The writing here was also top notch leaving me ashamed of myself for laughing audibly at some of the wittily acidic language used, most expertly by Hill, in the frenetic banter that drives many of these scenes.

It is always a solid endorsement when a 180 minute film flies by as fast as WoWS does and there is rarely a moment in this non-stop bacchanal where I wasn't totally entertained.

The Wolf of Wall Street provides one of the greatest satires towards Wall Street and materialism period, and in the end showing why nothing materialistic matters. The most important part would be the tragic hero of Jordan Belfort, as throughout the movie he has chances to change and improve, to finally live his life after he has millions in luxury, and yet greed and materialism become his hamartia and he's set to fail, loosing everything in a heart-breaking sequence. Another brutally depressing scene was the marriage problems between Naomi and Leonardo, which was bad enough with the yelling, cussing and violence but my stomach dropped when they had to get the kid involved, and it's so depressing to know this is what happens, and that not everyone in life has it easy, even the rich. This is honestly a movie that I would self reflect on, as Jordan Belfort is in a strange way a role model: by the end, he realises the corruption of Money and how life is better without materialism in mind, best summed up by the quote at the top.

Leonardo's range was phenomenal- I mean for the duration of the movie, he intrinsically embodied every emotion humanly possible, beautifully depicting the detrimental effects of drug use. He also provided a profound insight into the apparent daily life of a stockbroker & how he gradually gained his status. Although this superior position did simultaneously land him in trouble, (being involved in white-collar crimes) ultimately causing his kingdom to be demolished, it essentially exemplifies how the people we surround ourselves with have the power to change our lives so drastically. On top of that, They sublimely illustrate intricate character development, where he's practically an utterly different person towards the end, due to losing himself to greed & ultimately being morally conflicted- thereby making questionable decisions. I definitely feel this movie isn't for everyone with its excessive, unsolicited sex scenes, but its bizarre plot is worth watching.
i liked the movie and it was fun to qwatch
Amusingly dark and manages to allow me to enjoy watching a movie about the most heinous industry of greed and corruption that still sucks the life out of the world. Thanks.

The Wolf of Wall Street" is a fast-paced, mad, over-the-top film experience showcasing the rise and fall of infamous stockbroker Jordan Belfort, played to glorious perfection by Leonardo DiCaprio. It carries all the components of a Scorsese film, but feels as if it takes it a bit further. While we're clearly not meant to root for the protagonist, you can't help but find his drive and ambition infectious. I'm not sure how accurate it is to the source material, but it never provides a dull moment. Truly one of the most entertaining films I've ever watched.

This Jordan dude really has found the best way of making money, supplying endless amounts of grubbiness to folks with low expectations and no social conscience. Large market to feed,
if you have the stomach and the psychopathy for it, which clearly he has in spades. Not one to watch if you like clever humour or anything slightly meaningful to watch.

This film is a fast-paced journey into the life of Jordan Belfort, the ruthless "Wolf of Wall Street" who defrauds investors to fund his extravagant lifestyle. This is depicted in a very extreme manner, with no bounds to the depravity of his delights, despite the fact that this video appears to be toned down from his real-life exploits. The filmmaker does a wonderful job of driving the audience along all of Belfort's exploits and misfortunes. Leonardo DiCaprio does an amazing job of portraying this charming, dynamic person.

Lo que hace especial a este película esta en como están estructurados los 3 actos. Con un construcción de personajes muy bien marcada y una evolución notoria con querencia en la historia. Y eso es lo que hace especial a esta película el como los personajes se van trastornando en conforme avanza la historia, ya sea en simbolismos como el poder o el dinero mismo. Simbolismos que se remarcan de manera muy natural en la trama. Comprendiendo el porque de sus acciones y empatizando con ellos a pesar de poder ser los antagonistas de la historia. El personaje de Jordan Belford, es muy interesante complementándolo con la gran actuación de Leonardo Di Caprio que junto a Scorsese te regalan un "Mesías" falso, el como trastorna a las personas, pensando exclusivamente en si mismo y como el de cierta manera el igualmente va perdiendo su identidad. Lo que te atrapa desde el primer minuto en esta película está en esa comedia saritica muy bien introducida, junto a actuaciones sobresalientes manejadas de la mano de uno de los mejores directores de todos los tiempos. En cada cuadro te puedes dar cuenta el que hace grande a Di Caprio y Scorsese. Una experiencia única en un camino que cada vez se va desmoralizando más. No importa de donde vengas el poder siempre te corrompe, para poder lidiar con la presión del "poder"

This is one of the fastest three-hour movies you'll ever watch. I really don't get what's not to like about The Wolf of Wall Street. It's wildly entertaining, includes multiple excellent performances (DiCaprio, Jonah Hill, Margot Robbie, and I must shout out LPOTL's Henry Zebrowski as "Sea Otter"), action, comedy, and a sick twist on the "rags to riches" story. The dialogue is a joy, with the lunch scene between Jordan Belfort (DiCaprio) and Mark Hanna (Matthew McConaughey), the scene when "the main group" is discussing the little person's rights for their party, and, of course, Belfort's pump-up speeches. How does the chest-beating not get your juices flowing?? I'm not sure if I have a favorite scene, but the "deposition scene" has stuck with me since 2013, especially Kenneth Choi's character. Don't get lost in all of the champagne and Quaaludes and cocaine and vodka, there's some really good information here about what Wall Street actually makes: nothing. Nothing tangible, that is. They don't create anything or (really) perform a service. McConaughey lays it out for you in the first 20 minutes. But you came for the yacht parties, prostitutes, helicopters, and drugs, and there's plenty of that. I loved the soundtrack — the usage of Laura Branigan's "Gloria" was sublime. I would've appreciated a "where are they now" of the main gang, but I suppose we were already at three hours. The Wolf of Wall Street is my type of big-budget movie.

Where to star with this film, first off it's incredible! Every scene of this film is engaging and left me wanting more! Leonardo Dicaprio shines in this film and his performance is truly amazing, and both he and Morgot Robbie have great chemistry throughout. This film is also incredibly funny and kept me laughing throughout it's almost 3 hour run time. All in all this film is truly a must watch for any lover of cinema as it is truly a modern day masterpiece! I give The Wolf Of Wall Street a 10/10.
Thoroughly entertaining movie but it relies a lot on shock value

Ambitious, hilarious and a classic bauta!
esta pelicula es muy divertida disfrutando del buen cine de Scorsese

The most self-involved piece of filmmaking I have ever seen. Regardless of how the actual person being portrayed lived at that time, Scorsese did not have to resort to the lengths that he went to in order to show the events that took place. Why such a renowned director allowed such gratuitous language and sexual content does nothing to add to the story and in fact detracts from the already stellar performance given by DiCaprio. Instead of truly examining the negative consequences of Jordan Belfort’s lifestyle, it portrays drug use and sex as humorous and without consequence. I was shocked to learn that this was in fact a Martin Scorsese film because it is so immature and lacks any depth. Instead of being objective about the life of this individual, Scorsese’s choices in this film don’t tell the audience that what Jordan Belfort did was wrong and instead becomes so involved with the “fun” of it that it feels like he’s mocking any sense of responsibility or accountability for one’s actions. Rather than have a morality at the core of the film, it arrogantly mocks morality. Unfortunately instead of it being really examined, Scorsese’s name being attached to it leads people believe it to be a masterpiece, and inflates the ego of a progressively ineffective director.
Fun. I love that it's based on a real memoir.
I just think that a movie that is about stolen money is funded by Jho Low who stole over a billion dollars from the 1MDB scandal in Malaysia and is still a Fugitive.

Scorsese displays all of his prowess here, injecting ‘The Wolf of Wall Street' with high-octane energy and pulling off a clever balancing act by taking a serious topic and delivering it with a light-hearted, humorous tone that makes the debauched adventures of some of Wall Street's unscrupulous scum-bags a hell of a lot of fun to watch. It doesn't delve too deep into the details of how Belfort did what he did, but instead focuses on the rambunctious characters and the more extravagant, salacious parts of their lifestyles. The cast, lead by a charismatic DiCaprio at the top of his game, is so entertaining to watch that the 3 hr run time almost flies by. Now, you could argue (and you'd be right) that Scorsese is glorifying Belfort's lifestyle and crimes, almost inviting the audience (who, let's face it, is almost certainly going to be mostly guys) to envy, if not flat out admire him in some sort of twisted way; to imagine how much fun it'd be to be him. You could absolutely throw that criticism at Scorsese*, but the question is, does that make it any less compelling and fun to watch? Hell no.

One of the many reasons The Wolf of Wall Street didn't sit right with me is that I couldn't tell what it was trying to say. It seemed to glorify what Jordan Belfort and his cohorts did instead of condemning it. And at some points, the movie that was trying to tell us about deplorable debauchery became deplorable debauchery itself. It's an interesting story featuring good acting, but overall it's just kind of disgusting.

Scorsese organizes the chaos of Wall Street white collar crime.

Director Martin Scorsese's crime comedy The Wolf of Wall Street (2013) is like getting hit by lightning while Leonardo DiCaprio screams in your face. It's a trip. Witness Wall Street's wolf Jordan Belfort as he convinces every young stockbroker to work for him to get paid and get laid. The price of being rich is eventually either jail or taxes, but the journey there is paved in luxury women, brand new expensive cars, hard drugs, and tailored suits with a prepared speech ready to get you to buy stocks to become rich at any cost. 

Martin Scorsese's direction is like getting punched in the face with a bowling ball. The Wolf of Wall Street is legit 3 hours long and feels like a half hour sports car race. Only Scorsese could make 180 minutes feel like 30 with a constant influx of stacks of  information, hilarious jokes, drug highs, and shocking orgies. We go from Belfort's poor beginnings into the actual daily stock trade calls from his startup firm, to the insane partying like no other film I've ever seen. 

Jordan Belfort's sheer audacity, pure arrogance, constant lying, gross prideful narcissism, blatant criminal stock trading, illegal money hiding in Swiss bank accounts, money laundering, and reckless spending were his fatal flaw. Scorsese paints a picture of Belfort as a charismatic, egomaniac who needed to be stopped whether for the ethical reasons of his law breaking or the moral reasons as he ripped off hundreds of shareholders of millions of dollars. Belfort certainly left his own trail of victims. 

Writer Terence Winter gives you every aspect and moment of Belfort's life. From naked beautiful women, hot strippers, pretty escorts, gorgeous wives, nice yachts, private planes, private helicopters, to mansions like you've never seen. Cheating on a scale you could not calculate. Endless lies, constant manipulation of investors and wives. It's all fraud, it's all illegal, and he got away with it for years. Belfort was quite the motivational speaker. He got all his employees to admire him, be loyal to him, and aspire to be him. He looked like he had it all, but behind the limelight are the shadows.

Fallen firm, penny stocks, to major blue stocks. From ripping off ignorant new investors with penny stocks to the 1 percent of their wealth. Launching an IPO for shoe designer Steve Madden in the midst of debauchery. Belfort was a self made stockbroker CEO and genius stock trader, yet he could not do it legitly, so it cost him everything. You hate the guy, yet I have to admit he really ended up getting away with everything in a way since he's doing just fine.

Belfort had SEC and FBI investigations and enquiries after him, which leads to surveillance in his home and phone taps on his lines. The federal government took tabs and observed everything Belfort did as the FBI prepped their case before sending subpoenas to Wall Street's most infamous stockbroker fraud ever. Belfort even tried to bribe and influence The Federal Bureau of Intelligence. The brass balls on this guy were unbelievable.

Cocaine, quaaludes, crack, weed, morphine, led to drug addiction and sex addiction. Let alone all the money dealing addiction or what I might call deplorable greed. Leonardo DiCaprio's acting is absolutely hilarious during his iconic quaalude drug trip sequence wherein he loses all motor function. The Wolf of Wall Street has to be Leo's funniest role and is like a logical extension of his con artist from Catch Me If You Can, Howard Hughes from The Aviator, and Jay Gatsby from The Great Gatsby. DiCaprio portrays Jordan Belfort as the real life Gordon Gecko from Oliver Stone's Wall Street. Only Leonardo DiCaprio could express such exhilarating energy, erratic humor, absorbing charisma, and striking drama as Belfort's unreal life experiences are on full display.

Thelma Schoonmaker's editing is structured rigidly and flows effortlessly from trades to sex to traitors in a flash. Rodrigo Prieto's cinematography makes great use of the enormous amount of extras and bright lighting with his creative and playful wide shots. His close-ups are hard hitting and let you focus on the earnest character moments, but so much of The Wolf of Wall Street is Prieto's tasteful wide shots of Belfort's deals and parties.

Bob Shaw's production design recreates 80's Wall Street to a tee, whether it is the yachts, mansions, or stock market offices. Ellen Christiansen's set decoration is so perfectly tacky, bright, and gaudy, exactly right for Belfort's lavish tastes. Sandy Powell's costumes are immaculate to the late 80's and early 90's era with a fashionable spark. Mindy Hall's make-up has everyone done up to the nines with sleek style.

All the supporting roles are incredible from the drop dead gorgeous Margot Robbi as Belfort's wife Naomi Lapaglia. She gives it her all from full frontal nudity to her subtle dramatic acting with her inner disdain for Jordan to her crazy fights with Belfort. Jonah Hill is a riot as the partying stockbroker executive Donnie Azoff. Kyle Chandler is thoughtful and intense as the FBI agent Patrick Denham, who follows Belfort's paper trail. Rob Reiner goes nuts as Belfort's father, Jon Bernthal is a quaalude dealer turned money smuggler for Belfort, Matthew McConaughey sets the tone as the cringe inducing off the wall stock trader CEO who mentors Belfort, and Jean Dujardin is funny as the Swiss banker Belfort uses to hide money in Switzerland's tax haven banks. Cristin Milioti is tender, lovely, and funny as Belfort's first wife Teresa Petrillo.

In all, The Wolf of Wall Street is Martin Scorsese's most instantly entertaining and funny picture as he captures Jordan Belfort's exploits, excesses, and irresponsible actions.

However, the excessive level of obscene antics paints a sensationalized picture of white-collar crime, serving as an Achilles' heel to authentic representation. This particular criticism doesn't override my interpretation of "The Wolf of Wall Street" as a cautionary tale of the pursuit of power and greed at the expense of ethics.

The Wolf Of Wall Street - 10/10. The Wolf Of Wall Street is an interesting biopic, directed with speed and finesse by the legend himself, Martin Scorsese. Leonardo Dicaprio pulls off a career defining performance as the slimily charismatic Jordan Belfort, a penny stock pusher who ends up screwing over thousands of people. Scorsese shows the excess and extravagance of this horrible character, but he doesn't sympathize with the character. The character boasts about their exploits and life, but what Scorsese does is show how that seemingly great life begins to crumble down as the film progresses. He isn't a role model, and whatever he did to cut corners and become a rich man becomes his hinderance as the film moves on. Its a brilliant tale, which also shows how regular and moral based individuals also get affected by characters like this. Many people might criticize this film for its over indulgence and its over the top sequences, but its necessary to show the film this way, as it shows that whatever seems like a great time, might not be that way. With some amazing acting, great directing, and an interesting character arc, The Wolf Of Wall Street is one of Scorsese's best, and quite possibly one of his more underrated films.

The Wolf of Wall Street is one of the modern masterpiece. A movie about the life in the business in one of the busiest area in the world, The Wall Street. A sad yet dirtily dramatically true story on the life a successful businessman. This movie told a tale of a man named Jordan Belford, which is portray by Leonardo Dicaprio, how he became something from literally nothing. But, whenever there's an up, there's always a down. He started from finding a job from a news paper to a multi-billionaire and back to nothing.
	The movie's intention is to show to gruesome side of how people make a living. By the end of the movie you will either feel the attachment to Belford or just straight-up in your faced. The movie seems like everything has been planned, thanks to the incredible work from Martin Scorsese, the director. Every action from every single actor is very well portrayed. Even all the side actor's performance all adds up to the movie as a whole.
	In summary, "The Wolf of Wall Street is an outrageous and repugnant reflection of something very real - and very rotten - at the core of our society." From Screen Rant. And "Director Martin Scorsese, assisted by his longtime editor Thelma Schoonmaker, keeps up an astoundingly intoxicating pace for nearly three hours."  From Common Sense Media explain the movie very well with those words. I cannot do anything else but to recommend you to watch this movie if you are into business, drama, and good acting.

The Wolf is quite frankly one of the most popular films of our generation. Despite the massive run time it's a movie that everyone has literally seen and wants to watch over and over. It's just such a crazy and wild ride throughout. Jordan Belfort's rise and fall is just a mental story. It's one that if you didn't know it was true you would not believe. The things he does and gets up to are quite incredible. Drunk driving a helicopter though is something that I personally would not want to try. The rise of his company is amazing and how they got to the top is an even crazier story. It's one you have to see. 

You also need to see this movie as it's the greatest performance of Leo's career. That is quite some achievement as he's usually incredible in anything he's in. This movie though for me is his pinnacle. He may not have won an Oscar for the film but he was extremely unfortunate not to. He won an Oscar for The Revenant but for me he was given that as the award show realised they did him wrong by not giving him one for his performance here. The amount of energy and charisma he exudes in this film is incredible. Every time he's on screen he makes it wroth your while. He captures your attention with his performance throughout and he nails every different scenario he's thrown into. It is truly one of the greatest performances of our time and it's one that will be spoken about for years to come. 

Quite honestly when you have Leo and Scorsese together in a film you have a winning formula. They've combined before for greats such as The Departed & Shutter Island. Anytime they combine it just works. Scorsese really brings the best our of Leo and when he's at his best there's not many actors like him. 

You may or may not have been put off in the past because of the long run time of this film but believe me it is worth the 3 hours of your time. The amount of craziness on screen combined with some absolute belters of performances make it go quickly. Not only is Leo at his best but this is one Jonah Hill's best ever performances as well. He's another top actor who here gives us a perfect complimentary performance to Leo. Margot Robie as well just exudes sex appeal. I don't think we will ever have a performance like hers again. She literally is perfection in this role and now she's one of the biggest stars in Hollywood all from her brilliant performance here. 

The Wolf Of Wall Street is one of the best biopics ever made. Jordan Belfort is a really detestable person but Leo brings so many different sides of him to the screen. It really is a film that every single person must see. There's so many reasons you must see it. To think this is a true story is still something that blows me away. If you haven't seen it now is finally the time for you to sit down for an afternoon or evening and watch it. Trust me you'll love it.

Martin Scorsese's "The Wolf of Wall Street" is a bold, darkly comic and extremely entertaining biopic that sheds light on the hedonistic life of Jordan Belfort. With his twenty-third feature, Scorsese crafted an exhilarating film about the outrageous life of  Jordan Belfort. It's the filmmaker's first attempt to dramatize the hedonistic life of a corrupt stockbroker on Wall Street, but he pulls it off seamlessly. Using captivating cinematography, Scorsese draws viewers into the world of a corrupt scammer. Scorsese effectively employs fourth-wall-breaking shots to put viewers into the deranged mindset of the main character. In terms of writing, the film is elevated by an exceptional screenplay. Terrence Winter's screenplay is spectacular, and expertly uses voice-over narration to tell Jordan Belfort's outrageous life story. It is hard to not admire the astonishing performances from the cast. Leonardo DiCaprio delivers one of the best performances of his career as Jordan Belfort. This is the actor unlike you've ever seen him before: intense, charismatic and reprehensible in his first ever comedic role. The supporting cast, which includes the scene-stealing Jonah Hill, is also excellent and worthy of recognition. Although "The Wolf of Wall Street" is undeniably exhilarating, ultimately it is not a flawless film. At nearly three hours, it suffers from a lengthy running-time that tests the viewer's patience. Moreover, the film's graphic depiction of sex, drug abuse and debauchery may not appeal towards everyone. Nevertheless, fans of Martin Scorsese will definitely enjoy "The Wolf of Wall Street" and so will movie-goers seeking exhilarating entertainment. At a time when Jordan Belfort remains a controversial public figure in America, it's a rousing reminder that the lives of scandalous stockbrokers are worth depicting on the big-screen.

By taking authentic source material, while slightly deviating it from the truth, he created this MASTERPIECE, inspired by Jordan Belfort's real story, and his autobiographies.

Terrance Winter & Martin Scorsese did a PHENOMENAL job telling this story. The narrative has so many memorable scenes, amd tremendous layers, that holds so much rewatch value! After watching countless videos on the true story, and what the real Jordan Belfort (who was also on set for the production) thought; all of these seemed to be fantasy's, were almost all true, and immaculately presented! According to Belfort, Scorsese & Winter's dumbed things down! Not only was this the best paced out, three hour film I've seen, but probably one of the greatest films I've seen, in general - I was so intrigued from minute one, all the way to minute one-hundred-eighty!

The screenplay by Winter's was super creative & and so much fun! He added so many great layers to each character, giving them their own distinct personalities. The script was so vulgar, yet very witty, while still being ridiculously funny.

Even though Martin Scorsese & Terrace Winter's flipped some of the names, and some being made up completely, due to secrecy reasons, this A-list cast had such inspiring charisma, and displayed all the real actions, tremendously! I have seen A LOT of films, and more than a few Dicaprio films, but this was hands down the best acting I've seen across a cast, but giving tremendous credit to Leonardo DiCaprio, who got snubbed for an Academy Award for his performance! His anti-hero swagger, with such an engrossing personality, brought an abundance of charm, wit, and tons of comedy to this film. His love life was also nailed to a T! Margot Robbie's character development in the third act compliments the tone it was going for. The way Scorsese displays their relationship was pretty accurate, almost all the way down the line. Dan Porush, named Donnie Azoff in the film, played by Jonah Hill, is Jordan's second in command. Jonah Hill put on a FANTASTIC performance; definitely my favorite performance of his. I also thought Jonah Hill was snubbed for an Academy Award. Jonah Hill embodied Dan Porush to a T, down to his wife, his ambitions attitude, and everything else around it. As far as the strattonites go, in Henry Zebrowski, Kenneth Choi, Brian Sacca, Jon Bernthal & P.J Byne, they had the most chaotic roles out of everyone, on the side of Leo. Every character knew their role, and played it to perfection. I loved Rob Reiner in this film, even though he wasn't that important. His crazy dad attitude was displayed clear as crystal, and was an overall great addition! Matthew McConaughey had another small, but important role in Jordan Belfort's character development. After doing further research, McConaughey had a lot more of an impact than his screen time allowed. One of my favorite additions to this film, was Bo Dietl, playing Belfort's PI. Bo Dietl was the actual PI of the real Jordan Belfort. His character was just another small, but necessary addition, with such an effortless performance, due to Dietl playing himself.

The editing by probably one of the most credible editors in the game, in Thelma Shoonmaker, who edited all of Scorsese's films, had a tough task at hand. This film was 3 hours long, so I can only imagine how many deleted scenes there were, and what the run-time would've actually been, without so many cuts, and mashes. Shoonmaker did make some scenes a little obvious that they were two scenes mashed together, or shot at different times, but it's hard to fault someone with that much on their plate, with that much of a hefty resumé.

Overall, this is in my top five FAVORITE films of all time, and I HIGHLY recommend this film. Another film you MUST see before you die.

What can I say. The wolf of wall street is an undoubtedly a popular motion picture, for reasons I am yet to discover. I don't think it is fair to discredit what an incredible actor our star Leonardo Decaprico is, but I'm happy to poke enough holes in the storyline so that it falls apart. 

Jordan Belford, simply a con artist who, when he captured onto trickery and deceitfulness ,used  it to gain power and wealth beyond belief. Belford abused this wealth, commonly using it on drugs and hookers.  He didn't care about the wellbeing of others even those he seemed most close to such as his wife. His wife, played by the infamous Margot Robbie, was a blonde bimbo of a trophy wife. Who was abused emotionally, physically and once sexually by her greedy power hungry husband. I, personally, am terrified that this movie is based upon real life events and makes me disappointed to live in a world where men can rise through the ranks so much so that this behaviour is justified by wealth and social standing.  

Let's go into the storyline. I watched this movie across three days, each time thinking "when the hell is this going to conclude". For a movie that runs for three hours the narrative was very repetitive. Switching commonly between three themes, drugs, sex and shady office work. When we weren't watching bouncing breasts bobbing up and down on the screen, we were probably seeing Belford and his co-workers  snorting long lines of cocaine. For all those who say that Belford was a genius when it came to business and trading, I beg you to remember the very first scene of the movie when we see Belford snorting, what I'm assuming is his favourite drug, cocaine out of one of his prized hookers asses. The question must be asked; was he really all that? Or was he just a lucky fella who, though once was a nice person with some sense of human decency, became cocky, conceded and abusive when given power and wealth?  The reality is. Jordan Belford was a mad man. Driven crazy with limitless boundaries. 

As stated profoundly above, I think that Leo's acting cannot be overlooked here. It's no short of brilliant as he completely takes the form of any and all characters he portrays. His Oscar that he strived for wasn't won for his acting within wolf of wall street but instead won for a seemingly irrelevant movie that isn't even mentioned nowadays which is a true shame in my opinion. Because if you're going to make a three hour movie where in which you embarrass yourself with shoddy scripture and a bore of a storyline you might as well (as Leo did) do it well, and win an Oscar for it. Margot Robbie is in this movie alongside the predominant Jonah Hill both stand beside Leo in shining glory in regards to their dedication and acting. Margot Robbie in her dazzling beauty won over I'm sure everyone who watched her on the screen in wolf of wall street. Though to her beauty didn't come much intelligence or wit. Jonah Hill who loyally did drugs with Jordan,  stood beside him throughout his illegal dealings and basked in the limelight enjoying strippers and hookers. The two men though thick and thin became joint at the hip, needing crazier and crazier things to keep them going. The scene in which they were almost paralysed due to taking expired pills, leading them to stumble around like bumbling idiots was slightly ridiculous. 

All in all I think The Wolf of Wall Street should be a definite watch for anyone eighteen or over. The heavy use of drugs, nudity, sensitive scenes and profound language definitely warrants the eighteen plus rating that it is given. Though I stand by what I said about the storyline being terrible and the movie being 3 hours too long, I think its a terrible classic. Do not go with your parents or anyone actually. This is a film best enjoyed alone. That way you can freely think what you will about it, instead if being swayed by what other people might think about your thoughts on The Wolf Of Wall Street.

The Wolf of Wall Street has a lot of problems that stem from its long runtime. It often feels incredibly slow, so there are several scenes that are hard to sit through; a lot of the scenes feel like filler, unnecessarily added in to fill this film to the brim; a lot of the intricacies and layers of this film are bogged down, mainly because they have too much time spent on them. This film could have been a masterpiece if the runtime was cut down. It would be a lot more emotionally impactful, and it would be a lot more effective in its storytelling. 

Nonetheless, despite its slightly hit-or-miss writing and direction, the wonderful performances and its occasional cleverness makes it a fun and thought-provoking watch. It is definitely not a film for the casual viewer who wants a simple story or great visuals, but if you want to see a story about a bunch of greedy assholes making money, this is definitely the film for you.

Scorsese's 2013 picture is not a condemnation or a celebration of capitalism or toxic masculinity, as many have claimed. Like all great cinema, it is more complex. "The Wolf of Wall Street" is instead an outrageous dark comedy: snappy, funny, raunchy, and sometimes scathing, but always opulent. Similar to "Goodfellas," the film's glorification of the very behavior it wishes to indict becomes its edgy appeal. This is largely because the film's protagonist Jordan Belefort never seems even slightly remorseful for making his riches through shady penny stocks and pump-and-dump schemes and spending these riches on drugs, prostitutes, and other debauchery. "The Wolf of Wall Street" is defined by the cinema of excess. With a script penned by Terrence Winter and a virtuoso performance from DiCaprio, Scorsese merely presents Belfort's psychology, without judgement, and is not keen on moralizing or politicizing. Though Belfort may learn nothing, the audience can. This may sound cynical, but it is honest. The result is a 3-hour adrenaline rush, an unceasing bacchanal.

Many kudos to Martin Scorsese for what he did for the screenplay. This movie isn't like Martin Scorsese's bread and butter films, but he delivers and then some. His approach in this film is both refreshing, hilarious, and an absolute thrill.

The moral message underneath the film also shines upon the second visit. The film also (subtly) asks if it's ok to celebrate villainy and excess. Of course, the audience wants to cheer for the protagonist. But upon further thought, the viewers, like many of Belfort's victims have allowed him to pull another wool over our eyes. The image of excess covers the true financial crimes that Belfort committed.

The Wolf of Wall Street, directed by Martin Scorsese, is an example of an American success story set in the 1980's where young and eager Jordan Belford begins his journey rising through the ranks on Wall Street. The story demonstrates the lavish lifestyle of these individuals who act as a representation of American success. Money, power and drugs seem to be the driving influencers for Belford's extravagant lifestyle, and Scorsese beats this over the viewer's head relentlessly. He uses empathetic camerawork, throwing the audience directly into encountered as the result of his gluttonous drug use. Scorsese makes you connected to every one of Belford's experience, allowing the viewer to feel his every high and low as if they were right there with him. Overall this camerawork allows us to see and feel the way Belford felt, which ultimately lets us know how this commercially driven society impacts the choices and preferences of Belford. The people he becomes surround by enlighten him and further motivate his drive to indulge in the benefits of his success as a broker. However, these habits are what end up spiraling his life as he becomes to detach from others chasing nothing other than wealth and extravagance. People are interpreted as objects by Belford, only used to satisfy his desires. 
He loses a sense of humanity throughout the film, and we are given glimpses of his transition into a selfish and power hungry nature comparable to the animal kingdom. I believe Scorsese chose to literally place wild animals within Belford's office to represent this concept. He did not want to force this idea down the audiences throat, but rather subtly alludes to the parallels to make the views think harder about why animals were necessary to be put in the film. Further the title of the movie starts with the name of a vicious and powerful beast, the wolf. I think the comparison is most associated with the power hungry nature of not only Belford, but his followers as well. Belford is obviously the top wolf and those who chose to follow are his pack. Belford demonstrates his power yet his employees or the rest of the pack is just an extension of his power. However, this relationship works as the employees are inspired by the presence and success of the head wolf, which drives them to chase his level of prominence and to one day lead his own wolf pack. The film demonstrates this endless cycle of opportunity seekers who aspire to be as, if not more successful than those above them, and frames this as a negative pattern intended to highlight the pitfalls of greed.

Party on Wall Street--

The Wolf of Wall Street is a 2013 film directed by Martin Scorsese set in the late 1980s and early 1990s. The film follows the protagonist Jordan Belfort, played spectacularly by Leonardo DiCaprio, on his quest to fulfill his dream of becoming filthy rich. Jordan starts his empire by founding his own stock brokerage firm, Stratton Oakmont. Jordan uses his gift of persuasion to sell penny stocks to wealthy investors. Jordan's own greed, selfishness, and drug addiction lead to his ultimate demise. 

This story is a perfect example of the "Success Story" archetype. Jordan follows the American Dream and truly turns his rags into riches. Jordan arrives in New York hungry for success with a wife who is a hairdresser and almost no money to their names. He begins working at a large firm in a menial position on Wall Street and immediately becomes hooked. After finally becoming a licensed stock broker, Black Monday puts Jordan's firm out of business and leaves him without a job. Jordan eventually finds work selling penny stocks and builds his own empire. In just a few short years Jordan accumulates hundreds of millions of dollars. He owns a Ferrari, yacht, estate, helicopter, and more. Jordan even upgrades his wife to the beautiful "Duchess of New York," Naomi. Jordan's rise to success is coupled with his own inner turmoil. As he grows wealthier, Jordan develops sex and drug addictions that spiral out of control. 

One of the most compelling elements of this film is the protagonist, Jordan Belfort. Jordan is charismatic, witty, smart, compelling, callous, and crooked. This film incorporates both internal and external conflict. Jordan faces external review by both the SEC and FBI investigating his company and also struggles with sex and drug addictions. Jordan's character arch is interesting as he starts the film as a loser, develops into a winner, but is left as a loser at the end. His own greed causes him to lose sight of family, friendship, and morality.      

This film portrays the greed and corruption associated with Wall Street. I argue that The Wolf of Wall Street  is a critique of Wall Street. Unlike Oliver Stone's 1987 movie, Wall Street, greed is not glorified in this film. Stratton Oakmont defrauds wealthy investors of millions of dollars for their own profit. The firm avoids morality to chase profit at any cost. This film portrays Wall Street brokers as money hungry frat boys. The entire film feels like a mix of a frat party and business meeting. The film also has an underlying social commentary regarding workplace conduct, sexual misconduct, and abuse. The women are all highly sexualized in this film. The men are portrayed as sex-hungry animals. 

The resolution of the film is Jordan's sentencing to 3 years in prison. Facing over 20 years in prison, Jordan cooperates with the FBI to give up dozens of his employees. This resolution shows that wealth and money get people out of almost anything. Despite getting out of the majority of his prison sentence, Jordan has still lost his empire, money, wife, and children. 

This film is entertaining, funny, and exciting. Scorsese effectively warns against the dangers of greed and American capitalism while providing an interesting storyline and alluring protagonist.  I give this movie 5 out of 5 stars.

The Wolf of Wall Street - Rags to Riches

The Wolf of Wall Street is one of my all-time favorite movies. Leonardo DiCaprio plays a money-hungry young man from New York and his journey to take over Wall Street. The movie is hilarious, edgy, sad, and inspiring. It touches all areas of the emotional chart. Jordan's rags to riches story begin when he is a young man pursuing his dream of making a pile of money. His pursuit lands him on Wall Street, but that dream soon lands him on the rocks following Black Monday. He meets a man named Donnie, who becomes his business partner, and starts his own company. This is the start of the downfall of Jordan.

His rags to riches are somewhat fictional, as he decides to make his money with high-pressure sales tactics, pump and dump, and insider trading. The movie follows this journey from start to end.  Jordan had several opportunities to go legit and make money the ethical way but decides to chase the fast cash instead of doing right. His pomp and flashy ways are what lead him to the rocks soon after the release of Steve Madden's IPO. The decline is sharp and abrupt as drug addiction and unethical behavior wreck Jordan and every one involves lives. 

The character development of Jordan is excellent, as he goes from an innocent stockbroker to a chaotic millionaire. He dissolves into a frantic lunatic as he tries his best to evade the FBI and SEC, but the journey of Leonardo's character is brilliant. Overall, the movie is fantastic and a must-see. The film is dramatic and funny, and the character development of Leonardo DiCaprio's character is brilliant as he lives out his rags to riches story. I think what makes rags to riches stories so enjoyable is that it seems like the everyday person could make it and the film does a good job showing the everyday person how not to do it.

The Wolf of Wall Street is the 5th collaboration between director Martin Scorsese and star Leonardo DiCaprio. The film is the blackest of comedies based on the memoir of the same name by Jordan Belfort, who is rapturously played by DiCaprio. It's a three-hour, full-throttle rush into the lurid and depraved world of the corrupt stockbrokers who plagued Wall Street. Structurally similar to Scorsese's superior Goodfellas, the film tells the rise and fall of Jordan Belfort and his corrupt firm Stratton Oakmont, helped along by enthusiastic, sometimes compelling narration from Belfort. In some instances, the camera drops to eye level, and Belfort turns and speaks to the camera, coaxing us like one of his own foul-mouthed primal employees, except I doubt anyone viewing this film has snorted cocaine from a woman's backside, which literally happens a minute into the film – repeat this scene for three hours and you have The Wolf of Wall Street.

DiCaprio is outstanding in the lead role, selling every slimy word oozing from Belfort's silver-tongued mouth. His entire performance is dialled up to eleven from the start, and this ridiculous energy never lets up. It is a rapturous performance and you can see DiCaprio enjoyed every minute of it. Without his boundless energy and sheer force of will, the film would have been near unbearable.

Supporting cast comes in the way of Jonah Hill as his best friend and business partner Donnie Azoff. Jonah Hill is superb once again here, both funny and charming, following on from his solid work in films like Moneyball. Margot Robbie is striking as Belfort's wife, Naomi. Kyle Chandler plays Detective Denham who is out to get Belfort, appearing intermittently throughout the film, and I would have liked to see him given more screen time because he is the film's only moral compass. You can see the frustration and weariness in his eyes as he tries desperately to bring down these corrupt wealthy giants who do nothing but flaunt their illegal empires.

There is a great little scene that sees Denham riding an unglamorous subway home after finally seeing his targets arrested and there's a fraction of pride and satisfaction in Chandler's eyes. Not sex, not drugs or foul-mouthed slap stick comedy, this tiny scene is my favourite scene in the film. Unfortunately, this is as subtle as the film gets, everything else is surface level, which is disappointing given the talent involved.

This movie is hilariously funny despite the appearance of a non-coherent plot filled with meaningless jokes, this movie stays true to the goal of showing the rise and fall of Jordan Belfort. There is a lot of swearing and sex in this movie as is expected with Scorsese as a director. The movie does not shy away of all the atrocious acts Belfort does. You cannot get bored in this movie. DiCaprio's performance is absolutely comical along with his co-star Jonah Hill.

We open the Wolf of Wall Street with Jordan Belfort, Leonardo DiCaprio, introducing us to the various excesses of his life, his well-paid job, his beautiful wife, his guarded mansion and a myriad of other luxuries that he owns. We then flashback as he explains to us, again through voiceover, his beginnings as an earnest young stockbroker. We then see him become corrupted by figures like Mark Hanna, Matthew McConaughey, and pretty soon he's working as the head of a giant boiler room brokerage firm and rolling in cocaine and beautiful women.

It is clear that Scorsese has great fun directing the scenes that portray how outrageously excessive this figure is and many shots: a midget being thrown onto a plush dart board, a dominatrix torturing DiCaprio and on and on, are extremely memorable. The question that I have to ask is, what's the point? Is Scorsese saying that this excess is bad whilst also reveling in and selling it, essentially exploitation. Is he trying to portray how easy it is to be seduced by this ridiculous lifestyle as the audience is sucked into the life of this detestable human being. The film's lack of message has been criticized and when it purports to have a message, greed is bad, the imagery of the film seemingly works to directly contradict that. I think that whether the film has a message or not it is a hugely enjoyable viewing experience, a Goodfellas (1990) for the 2010s, and the iconic images it has produced alone make it a modern classic.

If Leonardo DiCaprio deserved to have awards showered on him for one role it should have been this. This is a role where we see him go absolutely crazy, without or vanity or any sense of pretension. We see him drugged out on Quaaludes, driving a luxury yacht maniacally in the middle of a tropical storm and several scenes of him snorting cocaine off the breasts of women. He is insane, but DiCaprio finds the humanity in him. The Revenant (2015) is a great film but it is more about the filmmaker's intent than DiCaprio's performance, he is a simply a vehicle to portray the suffering that people living in that environment during that era would have to face to survive. Despite this, it was the Revenant that earned him the award and he was left with loss on the night of the 2014 Oscars for a film that is far more iconic and will be remembered as one of his defining roles.

It is not just DiCaprio's performance that makes the film a worthwhile viewing experience with Margot Robbie in her breakout performance, Jonah Hill as a nebbish accountant and Matthew McConauughey in a hilarious small role. Robbie does wonders with a role that is severely underwritten, with a character that is clearly intended to be a pure sex object Robbie not only looks ravishing but suggests that she is in on the joke, all of her cheesiest lines "We're not gonna be friends" are said with a wink and she hints at the cynicism behind her character's faÃ§ade. Hill is on typically good form as the sidekick, as he was in Moneyball (2011), and complements DiCaprio well whilst McConaughey is perfectly disgusting as a smug, self-satisfied broker. Each actor does more with their outlandish character than you would expect and proves that each actor and actress possesses great talent.
The screenplay molds well to Scorsese's style with lots of voiceover, swearing and dark humor, often in unexpected places. Although Terence Winter, a television veteran with writing credits for The Sopranos and Boardwalk Empire, never reaches the heights of Goodfellas but does contain a lot of entertaining dialogue and some moments with real dramatic tension. Take for example the scene in which DiCaprio's first wife asks him if he loves Robbie's character, "Do you love her?" The screenwriter leaves enough open that the scene has room to be touching and sad, we care about his ex-wife and this is symbolic of him letting go of all morality, this would not have been achieved had he added extraneous dialogue.

This is a film that many young men enjoy in a similar way to how a previous generation enjoyed Scarface (1983), in that it is a film that purports to be against everything they like about it but this is certainly one of the easiest Scorsese films to watch and can be enjoyed by all. I would rank it as his seventh best film because I personally enjoyed the film despite it's lewdness and I understand this may be a drawback for younger audiences but I think for most it is a rollicking good time.

Incredibile come alla sua età e dopo numerosi capolavori Scorsese riesca a creare un film così fresco, moderno ed sorprendentemente giovanile. E non solo, si tratta di un'opera matura e solida sotto ogni aspetto, dalla creazione calibrata dei personaggi alle numerose scelte registiche che elevano la pellicola anche dal punto di vista visivo. Si tratta infatti di un film bello da vedere, con colori ricchi, una regia perfetta e uno stile narrativo veloce, che non perde tempo in inutili divagazioni. La volgarità eccessiva è il suo difetto più grande, non tanto per gli atti in sé che probabilmente sono anche successi veramente, ma più per la loro presenza martellante in un film del genere, creando un distacco stonato che non convince tutti gli spettatori. Leonardo DiCaprio semplicemente mostruoso, probabilmente la sua interpretazione migliore visto che il film funziona già per il cinquanta per cento grazie a lui. C'è un'assurda mancanza di una morale, che per quanto mi riguarda era assolutamente indispensabile e non riesce a far raggiungere al film il grado di capolavoro.

If you like comedy films, then you will like this film. The name of this film is "The Wolf of Wall Street. The movie was directed by Martin Scorsese. He also directs Taxi Driver. The film is a comedy and policial movie. It sets in the United States. More exactly in New York City at Wall Street.

The main actor of the film is Leonardo Dicaprio. He is very famous and talented actor. He receives an Oscar. One of the most famous films he acts in is Titanic, as Jack. In the film The Wolf of Wall Street, he plays the role of Jordan Belfort. He is a millionaire who makes crazy things with the money he gets off his stockbrokers company. Another actor who acts in The Wolf of Wall Street is Jonah Hill. He interpretes Donnie, the best friend and job partner of Jordan Belfort.

Jordan Belfort teamed up with his partner Donny and they founded Stratton-Oakmont, a brokerage firm. Their company grows fast and also their status in the business community. As their state grows, so does the amount of substances that they abuse. They attract attention like no other, throwing lavish parties for your staff when they reach so much money. That leads Jordan Belfort to appear on the cover of Forbes magazine, which is called "The Wolf of Wall Street". With the FBI watching him, he invents new ways to cover their tracks and grow their fortune. In conclusion, Jordan Belfort gives a plan to hide his money in a European bank.

Unlike the earlier film, where the main character ends up in their own personal hell (living in anonymity in suburbia), the main character here shows no remorse, no real change from his douchie ways. Hell, the real Jordan Belfort even gets a cameo in the movie base on his own book. Still, it is entertaining and well worth a look. I’m not judging those who enjoy movies like The Wolf of Wall Street, you are entitled to your preferred style of entertainment as long as it’s legal. However, I do not comprehend what it is that makes people enjoy this style of movie. It is a celebration of scumbags that spends hours more than it needed to explain the fact that disgusting people do a ton of terrible things without a care for others. I’m pretty sure this movie sets feminism back about 2 or 3 centuries as every woman in it is used, abused, and treated like an object to do the bidding of every man around them. We are expected to laugh at the results of excessive drug use because addiction, making fun of the handicapped, and putting the lives of other people at risk is hilarious! And don’t forget the important moral lesson of the film: Lying, cheating, and stealing are the best ways to get ahead (and don’t be afraid to do all of the above, because at worst you might find yourself in a prison that resembles a country club.) Besides, if you are a hard-working honest man who works to punish people for their crimes, you’ll just end up riding on the crappy subway for the rest of your life. I needed a shower after witnessing the sleaze of this movie, and found myself fast-forwarding through some of the prolonged scenes of debauchery. There’s a plot buried in it somewhere, but it’s not enough to even fill a short film. They drag it out to maximize the spectacle for 3 hours. The Wolf of Wall Street is a movie I found despicable, but I guess I’m in the minority.

Phenomenal direction from the brilliant Martin Scorsese, a hilariously outrageous fact-based screenplay from Terence Winter, vibrant camerawork with savvy attention-to-detail, an phenomenal performance from Jonah Hill, a stunning debut from Margot Robbie, and Leonardo DiCaprio's best performance to date make this one of the best films I've seen in a long time.

Apart from the frequent continuity errors, The Wolf Of Wall Street is a three-hour killer paced and adrenaline fueld film. The heavy swears, regular utilizing of drugs, and Leonardo's air-punching speeches will leave you addicted to the rush that Scorsese delivers in this Money laundering flick. For a lot of films, constant swearing can soon blend into pure annoyance and attempts to drive a scene, but with Scorsese's master direction, it naturally fits with the characters.

While stylistically in the vein of his "Goodfellas," but swapping mob guys for stock brokers, the pace and insanity of "The Wolf of Wall Street" is infectious and captivating. At a very long 3 hours, the story is very thorough and furiously entertaining to the very end. Dark comedies of this scale are rare. The performances of Leo, Jonah Hill and the large supporting cast were choreographed like a musical, which is a testament to the brilliance of Scorsese. It's almost unfair to see this within close proximity to a good film like "American Hustle" since "Wolf" makes "Hustle" look like a student film.

Whoa, here we go again! Now this is the kind of film that is offensive just like most of the Martin Scorsese films are. One of them starred Robert DeNiro and Leonardo DiCaprio. And now The Wolf of Wall Street came out and they loved it and it's based on true events and based on the memoir of the same name by Jordan Belfort played by Leonardo DiCaprio himself. Like most Martin Scorsese films nowadays this one is intense. This is in fact the fifth time Leonardo DiCaprio worked with Martin Scorsese. They previously worked with each other in Gangs of New York, The Aviator, The Departed and Shutter Island. Everyone is going on and on about Leonardo DiCaprio getting an Oscar for his performance as Jordan Belfort but instead won an Golden Globe Award for Best Actor - Motion Picture Musical or Comedy as for some reason this is actually a black comedy but it has loads of biographical drama. Now let me get to something what is really important. Everybody loves The Wolf of Wall Street because your mum loves Leonardo DiCaprio and your dad loves to look at Margot Robbie. And you should't be watching it with your parents because why? Sex, drugs, nudity and up to 569 uses of the F-word. Martin Scorsese is known for making films that contains alot of swearing for the most part and if you're looking for a kid friendly film from Martin Scorsese, check out Hugo because everything else he's ever directed is never going to be child friendly. But if you regret watching a Martin Scorsese film with your Mum and Dad, The Wolf of Wall Street will be a prime example. That being said, The Wolf of Wall Street is a fantastic amazing film, lots of great acting by all cast especially from Leonardo DiCaprio. Although the film is 3 hrs long but that just makes the biographical moments look so epic and fantastic. The Wolf of Wall Street is one of the best films of 2013.

Leonardo DiCaprio is one of my favorite actors of all time. So, when I saw The Great Gatsby, I was heavily disappointed. Luckily, Leo righted the ship later in the year with The Wolf of Wall Street. It's arguably the best performance of his career and the film is must-see for that reason alone. DiCaprio is at his best when paired with Martin Scorsese (see Gangs of New York and The Departed) and that rings true again here.

The film is not without issues. At just under three hours, it runs long, especially in the second half. There are a few scenes that could've been cut out or at least cut short. A scene where Leo meets with his aunt by marriage while in Europe particularly overstays its welcome. Other than that, this fires on all cylinders. The writing, directing and acting are all great. Jonah Hill is actually a standout in that department, playing his character with just the right blend of loyalty and sliminess. Jordan Belfort is also portrayed in fascinating fashion. He's a layered character that leaves the viewer in between loving him and hating him. 

One thing I didn't expect, was for this to be so damn funny. I knew it ventured into comedy at times, but parts of it had me in stitches. The scene where Belfort takes the drugs with the delayed reaction is hilarious. Watching DiCaprio drag himself into his car and then get into a fight with Hill had to be some of the finest work of either man's careers. Ridiculousness like that is perfectly intertwined with the tale of a man who seemingly had it all, yet was never satisfied and it led to his downfall.

It's hard not to be completely enthralled by this. Leonardo DiCaprio deserved his Oscar win for this and it's another hit for Scorsese. It's one of the best films in recent years, led by great direction, stellar performances and a witty script. The only issue is that it goes a bit long

SCOTT: (Dr. Scott Allison, Professor of Psychology, University of Richmond) Greg, looks like we have an encounter with the big, bad wolf. Hope he doesn t eat Little Red Riding Hood s grandmother.

GREG: (Greg Smith, Founder of Agile Writers of Richmond, VA) The Wolf of Wall Street is based on true events - it makes me pine for the 90s.

SCOTT: The Wolf of Wall Street opens with young Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio) starting a new job as a stockbroker at an established Wall Street firm. His boss Mark Hanna (Matthew McConaughey) asks him to lunch and tells him that the key to success is to encourage investors to make more and riskier investments. Hanna also tells Belfort that successful brokers drink, drug, and womanize to great excess. Black Monday causes Belfort to lose his job, but his aggressive salesmanship soon earns him a small fortune selling penny stocks.

GREG: Belfort doesn t take long to realize that penny stocks are flying under the radar of the SEC and he starts his own company  Stratton Oakmont.  He hires his marijuana-selling buddies and soon they are making millions of dollars. That s when Forbes magazine interviews Belfort labeling him  The Wolf of Wall Street.  The article also attracts the attention of the FBI and Belfort begins his descent.

SCOTT: Greg, this movie is all about bloated excess, and we see it in full force on two different levels. On one level there is, of course, the lavish excess shown by Belfort and his staff at Stratton Oakmont. They partake in prodigious bouts of drinking, drugging, and womanizing. The overindulgence of physical pleasure and the trappings of living a corrupt, greedy life are clearly on full display here. There is also bloated excess in the filming of this movie. Martin Scorsese needed to be reigned in here, big-time. There are far too many scenes of Belfort and Azoff (Jonah Hill) reveling in their inebriation, their toxic injections, their boorish behavior, their prostitutes, and their abuse of women in general. How many times do we need to see frenzied, infantile men snorting cocaine, popping quaaludes, and having random sex? The Wolf of Wall Street is basically Animal House on steroids, an endless orgy of excess in both the characters  actions and the filmmakers  ego-feeding editing choices.

GREG: I agree with you to a point, Scott. The film clocks in at just 3 hours which was an hour more than the film needed. But Scorsese is a genius and nobody edits Scorsese. I thought it was necessary to show just how over-the-top these young men had gone. They believed they were above the law and above morality. But, yeah, a few of those scenes could easily have been cut. I thought this was sort of the opposite side of The Great Gatsby (also played by Leonardo Dicaprio). In Gatsby we have a leading man who worked hard to create a lavish lifestyle so that he d be worthy of the woman of his desire. He apparently has no other woman in his life. Belfort, on the other hand, creates wealth for the sake of having as much sex and drugs as he wants. His money isn t there to make him worthy of anything other than living as extreme a lifestyle as he possibly can.

SCOTT: I just didn t understand the point of this movie, Greg. There are no heroes here, just a couple of jerks who get rich by cheating people. They are neither tragic heroes nor sympathetic figures. They re merely losers and villains whom we hope will get their comeuppance. Does the story teach us something about the downfall of humanity? I suppose it can serve as a cautionary tale, but like you said, lopping an hour off the three hour running time would have helped make this bloatation much more palatable. One positive observation I d like to make is that this movie features an extraordinary performance by Leonardo DiCaprio. This role showcases his impressive range as an actor, thanks to the volatility of the character he plays. I wouldnt have thought that DiCaprio was capable to handling the character of Belfort, who is a complex and broken man hell-bent on harming others to benefit himself. As much as I disliked this movie, I believe DiCaprio deserves an Oscar nomination for Best Actor.

GREG: Scott, you re right when you say there are no heroes here, at least not in the classic sense. But I think Wolf is in the same category as other films we have reviewed this year - that of the anti-hero. We see this same pattern in American Hustle where none of the players has any moral character. We also saw this in Pain & Gain where main characters were hoodlums. I think we like to see the decadent side of life. In the case of American Hustle we see an FBI agent who is overcome by his desire to be a great agent. In Pain we see three men who want to take another man s wealth. And in Wolf we see Belfort who rises to the top and gains everything only to lose it to his greed. I think all three of these stories are cautionary tales and align pretty well with mythological stories that want to teach us a lesson: be successful, but keep your head.

SCOTT: At least we see the lead character in American Hustle show compassion and attempt to make a change in his life. In The Wolf of Wall Street, the villainous lead characters are villainous to the bitter end.  I m afraid the wolves in this movie were just not worth watching, especially not for three hours. I do admire Scorsese s movie-making style, and DiCaprio delivers what is arguably the best performance of his career.  For those reasons I m willing to generously award Wolf 2 Reels out of 5. There is no hero story at all, no transformation, no positive mentoring, no sign of the classic hero journey.  Just a steady downward spiral for our villains. For that reason, I can only give this movie 1 Hero out of 5. Movie:  Hero: 

GREG: I agree that The Wolf of Wall Street is a masterfully created film. Martin Scorsese delivers and wrings the most from his actors. This is clearly the story of rise and fall of a giant. I did see an arc here. Bermont starts out innocent, is corrupted by an anti-mentor in the form of his boss (played by Matthew McConaughey). You and I have been talking about reviewing villains in 2014 and I think this is the origin story of a true villain. Our  hero  loses his caring and selflessness and becomes corrupt. Then we watch him fall from the highest of heights to the lowest of lows. It s a skillfully produced story and one I m willing to give it 3 Reels out of 5 (I would have gone to 4 if it had come in under 2 hours). I think we re going to have to give considerable thought to anti-hero stories in 2014. We ve seen a few this year and there is a clear pattern. Belfort, in my mind, qualifies as an anti-hero. He doesn t fit our usual expectations of heroes in the classic sense so it is difficult to give him a hero rating. But since he can be held up as a cautionary tale, I m going to give him 3 out of 5 Heroes. Movie:  Hero:
