Arguably this is the best performance of Leonardo DiCaprio's long, successful career With DiCaprio's Oscar winning role in 'the revenant' as a close runner up. However good the acting of Jonah hill or the directing talent of Martin Scorsese, the unsung hero behind this film is the writer Terence winter. It is quite amazing how a film which lasts over 3 hours does not bore you within its dialogue as it's kept witty, clever and interesting throughout its run time. The direction of the film is in typical Scorsese style of freeze frames, tracking shots and narration, although used again and again it never fails to keep your attention. While this film has received endless criticism for promoting the lifestyle of a wealthy stockbroker (I.e excessive amounts of drugs, solicitation of prostitutes, fraud etc), it is undoubtedly hard to not enjoy as every single character in one way or another are likeable and this works so well that when coming to the conclusion of the film you are still rooting for the morally twisted Jordan Belfort to beat the system. Wolf of Wall Street is a instant classic.

Film Review 
                                                   The Wolf Of Wall Street
The Wolf of Wall street is an autobiographical account of a Wall street Broker, Jordan Belfort. Shot in a first person narrative, the movie portrays the hectic and erratic lifestyles of Wall Street Brokers. Filled with drugs, prostitutes and strippers, the movie implies that in order to work efficiently in Wall Street, one must have an indulgent lifestyle and have absolutely zero conscience when it comes to cheating or scamming people. The movie starts of by showing Jordan Belfort (Leonardo Di Caprio) as a newlywed man in his early twenties who comes to New York with dreams of becoming a Wall Street Broker. He is shown to be a very decent and naive man who with his young wife wants to make it big on the street and become a millionaire ultimately. The movie portrays that by showing him going to his first place of work at L.F Rothschild in a bus. This is very symbolic of the urban middle class in New York. This scene attempted to show that he came from a very humble beginning. Even his interactions with the people at his new work place show him to be very nervous, he is constantly stuttering and genuinely seems confused and many a times lost and doesn't seem to understand the instructions given to him. This changes when he meets Mark Hanna played by Matthew McConaughey, he teaches him how to be a good broker by telling him about his lifestyle and teaches him how to be more tough and unapologetic about taking money from people. He is the first person who introduces him into the world of drugs and strippers in order to be a sane broker. It is at this point at the movie we see a first glimpse of what will ultimately become "THE JORDAN BELFORT". As he becomes more and more confident and successful in his brokering skills, we see that he becomes more and more ruthless he starts to lose his naivety and decency. This can be scene in the scene where he loses his first job during the Wall Street crash and joins a Penny Stocks company, here he shamelessly uses the "Pump and Dump" strategy without any remorse or sadness, even though he knows he is selling his stocks at a very high price to his buyers. He knows what he is doing is illegal but chooses to do it anyway. Here we see that he is transformed into a man with no conscience and he is slowly becoming a mechanical money making machine. He then along with his flat mate Donnie Azoff(Played by Jonah Hill), open a Stockbroking company called Stratton Oakmont. Together they create an empire, this is shown by Jump Cuts showing the expansion of Stratton Oakmont and the increase in their employees. He does so by giving his employees a script to tell to their buyers, he tells them that they have to be very confident in the way they pitch stocks to their customers. He convinces them by successfully selling a stock to a random customer at a very high price and at the same time ridiculing the stupidity of the customer. The movie implies that stock brokers heavily mystify the actual workings of the system. It means that just the use of a confident tone in pitching can so easily sway a customer into buying a stock or not. The movie makes the stock market seem like a very simple job and subtly implies that people who invest in stocks are very greedy and their subconscious can be easily tweaked by the use of words to want more money. Even though the technical details about the market are hard to understand the movie does a good job of making its viewers understand that whatever Jordon is doing is illegal and that he earnt a lot of money by doing just that. They do so by showing his many magnificent parties, the drugs he used to take and consume and also his House. Even though initially a viewer might find his dishonest ways distasteful, viewers slowly grow into liking his lifestyle because of the brilliant way the movie portrays it. They show Donni and Jordan acting like mad, crazy and ratchet buffoons, triumphing in their glory and fortune. Jordon also goes as far as to bribe a federal agent who was onto his wrongdoings. The first person narrative given by Jordon throughout the film reiterates the fact that he is rich and has a lot of money and he leaves no ends turned to brag about it. 
It is during this time that we also see a shift in his personality and at this point he is very arrogant and proud about his money and fortune. This is in stark contrast to the Jordon we saw in the earlier part of the film. The movie makes the audience realize how much Jordon has changed as a person since the time he moved to Wall street. He is actually completely different person. They do so by showing how he divorces his ex-wife and marries Naomi(played by Margot Robbie) who was a model. This attempted to show how he has detached completely from his old life. He is now a new man and is the Wolf of Wall Street as the title of the movie suggests. In the film Jordon sort of falls in love with his new lifestyle and is very insecure that this might be taken away from him. The audience can see as the film progresses Jordon becomes more and more cautious and nervous about how he handles his funds and money. From storing his money in his wife's aunts Swiss-bank account and becoming sober we slowly see him transitioning to his old self at the end of the film. This is fully realized when Jordon gets caught in a wiretapping allegation and is sent to 3 years of prison This is where we see him going back to the old Middle Class Jordon. Of course we do not see his wife but we see him becoming humbler. This was after his wealth was confiscated and he truly becomes the old Jordon in terms of wealth and personality. At the end of the film he makes money of teaching people sales techniques and we see this as a representation of a middle class American man with a mediocre job. The film showed a man who used to live a boring, mundane life which then transitioned into a one of a rich fast paced life which then ultimately culminated into him returning to his old life and self but also made him discover his talent which was excellent pitching skills.

The Wolf Of Wall Street is the fifth collaboration between actor Leonardo Di Caprio and director Martin Scorsese.It a black comedy and a character-driven film based on the memoir of Jordan Belfort,a New York stockbroker who ran a firm that is involved in securities fraud and corruption at Wall Street during the 1990's.Jonah Hill, Margot Robbie and Matthew McConaughey co-stars.

The film is similar to many of Scorsese's genre of gangster films such as Goodfellas and The Departed.But this time,we get to see the anti-hero Belfort,played charismatically and excellently by DiCaprio dumping fake stocks that are worth nothing instead of killing and murdering people.Aside from that,it explores Belfort's character,a young Jewish broker from New York looking to make his way in Wall Street.He starts off at J F Rothstein and he is quickly taken into an understudy by lead broker Mark Hanna,who teaches him how to make money without morals and integrity.He then finds himself trading penny stocks and sets up his own operation.As his business grows exponentially,he tries to make it into the legit business which goes awry as they soon find themselves conning thousands of businessmen out of their cash.This leads to an FBI investigation on his part.Aside from his business that consists of greed and scams,we get to see Belfort's lifestyle that is characterized by excess that includes sex,drugs,parties and orgies.

Despite the fact that it is 180-minutes long,one will surely enjoy the ride of watching this film.DiCaprio and Scorsese makes it a point to make it interesting and entertaining.Despite the controversy it has made due to its themes of moral ambiguity and having a lot of amoral characters that are involved in a lot of sex and drugs as well as the constant use of vulgar language,it definitely epitomizes fraud and corruption in Wall Street during the 90's.Although many viewers have seen this film as it somewhat glamorizes Jordan Belfort and his lifestyle,it certainly is one great movie.In the end,this is one great film that will surely be enjoyed by many people.
One of the best movies ever!

The Wolf of Wall Street is a good film that was directed by the brilliant director Martin Scorcese who created a cinematic masterpiece. 
     The film is a movie adaptation of the autobiography of Jordan Belfort. Belfort is the owner of Stratford Oakmont who served three years in prison for defrauding investors for a massive securities scam and money laundering. Brody believes that "Its furious cinematic inventions are no mere flourishes; they're essential to Scorsese's vision of Belfort's story, and to the disturbing moral ideas that he extracts from it." (Brody). The life of Jordan Belfort was such an interesting and adventurous journey from his life as a meat broker to President of Stratford Oakmont. The film showed Belfort's hungry for sex, power and money through different stages in his life even if Belfort was already a family man and moral values do not matter as long as Belfort was getting all the best things in life. 
     Leonardo DiCaprio gave the funniest, unhibited, great performance in this movie. The main character of the movie is Jordan Belfort played by Leonardo DiCaprio. This is the fifth collaboration of DiCaprio with Martin Scorsese. Brody acknowledges that, "Leonardo DiCaprio, playing Belfort, he leaves impersonation behind and unleashes spontaneous bursts of energy that seem to tear through the screen" (Brody). One of the incredible performances of DiCaprio in the movie was when he was so drugged out (cerebral palsy face) that the actor crawled to his white Ferrari car rolled down the stairs and used his foot to open the door. DiCaprio captivated his viewers whenever the actor gave invigorating speeches to his employees with such convincing power that the recipients of the speech picked up the phone right away and made that investment producing call. 
	Jonah Hill played the character of Donnie Azoff, Belfort's partner in business, pleasure and crime. Hill played the part extraordinary well as can be seen when Azoff got high on drugs and fought with Belfort's in the kitchen struggling for air. Mark Brody states that "More or less the entire cast could fill the lists of nominees for supporting actors, especially Jonah Hill, as Donnie Azoff, Belfort's partner in business, pleasure, and crime." (Brody). Azoff's portrayal of a drug addict high on Quaaludes was close to the real thing as can be seen on his facial reactions and body movements.
	The performance of Margot Robbie was astonishing where she played the sexy and beautiful second wife of Belfort. Brody states that "her consonants alone, floating away at the end of words, deserve an Oscar." (Brody). Robbie was able to catch the attention of the viewers especially when she got into an argument with Belfort with regards to other women and their children. Viewers could see the strong emotions built up throughout the years of Belfort being a womanizer. 
	Martin Scorsese directed the three-hour movie that is known for his movies like "Color of Money", "Aviator", "The Departed", "Goodfellas", "Casino" and "Gangs of New York". Brody believes that "Scorsese's freewheeling direction captures the autobiographer's raunchy, discursive vigor. He also introduces a great device to impose the protagonist's point of view: Belfort narrates the action even while he's in the midst of living it, addressing the camera with monologues that show him to be both inside and outside the events, converging on-screen his present and former selves" (Brody). Here, Scorsese was able to capture Belfort's point of view through narration while going through the motion. Scorsese was able to bring a good cast together in the likes of Leonardo DiCaprio, Jonah Hill of "Money ball", Margot Robbie of "Pan Am", Kyle Chandler of "Argo", Matthew McConaughey of "Lincoln Lawyer", Jean Dujardin of  "The Artist" and Rob Reiner of "30 Rock". Scorcese brought together a great ensemble who showed emotional and moving performances all throughout the movie.
	The special effects used in the movie were so realistic and well done. There was a scene where the ship Naomi was sailing going to Monaco bracing the perfect storm with waves of 20 ft. high. And the viewers could see the realistic waves, storm raging through the ship breaking windows, flooding the ship and drifting helicopter. The aspect ratio, framing and camera focus was so carefully directed and shot by Scorsese with big attention details. The viewers could see how well Scorsese pan in and out of the character of Belfort's whenever he delivers a speech making sure Scorsese get all the reactions of the attendees as well as Belfort's reactions. With the film's budget of one hundred million, viewers could see the elaborate settings, expensive costumes and grandiose film locations in the U.S.A. as well as in Europe. 
	The musical scoring of the movie was a mixed of an orchestra and ninety's music. Jenkins claims that "The movie barrels through time and space, boosted by punky songs whose titles say it all: "One Step Beyond," "Never Say Never," "Uncontrollable Urge."(Jenkins). The choice of music was so applaudable, there was this scene in Belfort's house party where the employees were celebrating getting high on drugs and having sex then the music "Insane in the brain" was playing in the background. 
Proponents of bad reviews of the film "The wolf of wall street" make a strong case when Jenkins argues "Yet the zooming visuals don't propel the story to any place in particular. Sure, an FBI agent (Kyle Chandler) is nosing around, and Naomi eventually rebels against her husband's thing for other women, mostly hookers. But Belfort's character, such as it is, remains unchanged."(Jenkins) However this view overlooks how the overall story played together when Brody states "Scorsese's freewheeling direction captures the autobiographer's raunchy, discursive vigor. Scorsese unleashes a furious, yet exquisitely controlled, kinetic energy, complete with a plunging and soaring camera, mercurial and conspicuous special effects, counterfactual scenes, subjective fantasies, and swirling choreography on a grand scale." (Brody). The author believes the character of Belfort developed throughout the transitions in his career from being a meat broker up to the time of being the President of Stratford Oakmont. Belfort was able to redeem himself in the end from being a drug user to a sober Sales motivational speaker. The visuals used were so important in each scene to depict the excessiveness of one's addiction to drugs, women and money so viewers could take something from it. There was one scene in the movie where they braced the perfect storm and Belfort's still used drugs while in the middle of all the chaos. When the Italian coast guard rescued them, the plane that was supposed to pick up Belfort's family blew up due to seagulls going inside the engine of the plane. Belfort thought that it was a sign from God. From there, Belfort changed his ways; Belfort got sober and became a sales motivational speaker. 
Some viewers may challenge the view that the plot of the movie was not entertaining and well thought of. After all, many believe that the film only showed "various Cheech-and-Chong-style slapstick scenarios play out repeatedly, just with different props." (Jenkins). Indeed, this argument seems to ignore Scorsese's directorial masterpiece, which is supported by Brody when he states that "Brilliantly, Scorsese doesn't hide the story behind the story-he makes the planning of a repellently decadent party even more absorbing than the event itself, and somehow manages to make a self-administered enema seem like part of the fun." (Brody). In the movie Director Scorsese showed the bad practices in the Stock Market, family drama between Belfort and his wife and children, camaraderie between fellow Stratford Oakmont employees and on top of this there were drugs, humor and sex involved so it is full of entertaining scenes and captivating shots. Viewers will never get bored watching the film. 
Scorsese managed to extract astounding performances from his actors and in his latest collaboration with DiCaprio resulted in offensive, heinous and charming characters to ever appear on the big screen. As a movie, it is a must see.

Martin Scorsese is a master of the crime drama; time and time again he has woven detailed and thoroughly engaging criminal tales over the years that define standards in movie-making. He returns once again with ''The Wolf of Wall Street''; arguably his most light-hearted (yet still crazily entertaining) film to date.

Based on the memoir of the same name; ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' follows the life and times of Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio) a stockbroker on Wall Street who with his company Stratton Oakmont cheated both the economic system and his own clients to become rich and corrupt with wealth beyond his wildest dreams. All the while, Belfort must attend to the needs of family, friends, and a prying FBI agent named Patrick Denham out to bust him (Kyle Chandler). The film takes place across many countries and several decades that chronicle Belfort's rise and eventual fall in a similar way to Brian De Palma's ''Scarface''. Where Belfort's memoir contained a serious account of his brushes with the law, Scorsese's vision focuses on the opposite. ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' is insanely over-the-top in every conceivable way; whether it's the endless shouting, swearing, drug use and sex scenes or how Belfort's company is quite literally degenerated into a pack of rabid wolves, the film is a testament to how having all this money can corrupt beyond belief. The only problem with all this madness is that it can become very exhausting; a good half of the film is spent watching Belfort and company going completely crazy at parties and in the office. A more serious tone does arrive later but for those who appreciate a more controlled and focused crime drama experience, ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' will be rather jarring at first. Another niggling flaw is the theme of economics that persists through the film; unless you're a stout follower of the topic, most of the financial tones will go right over your head.

There may be a large cast present but in truth ''The Wolf of Wall Street'' is all about Jordan Belfort and Leonardo DiCaprio once again delivers a stellar performance all around. Belfort is a truly unforgettable character; his narrations of the plot draw you in and even though he spends most of the movie yelling through a microphone there's also moments where he can show some emotion; the scene where he goes ballistic at the prospect of divorce is particularly strong. Though they never hold the spotlight for too long, the side characters are also solid, especially Jonah Hill who completely nails the drug-addled Donnie Azoff, Belfort's right hand man. The other members of Stratton Oakmont stick to the basics; Jon Bernthal as a company courier, Jon Favreau as a security supervisor, and Rob Reiner as Belfort's father among others round off the cast and they play off the main leads well enough, making their presence known whilst never distracting from DiCaprio and Hill. These performances comes at a contrast with Kyle Chandler who is much more stable but often ruthless in his pursuit of Belfort and his cohorts. The writing as with many Scorsese films is sharp, witty and in this case possessed with a great sense of humour; in keeping with the film's over-the-top vibe the banter between characters and drug-infused shenanigans will often bring a chuckle from many a viewer. But the conversations also work to the film's detriment; there is a great deal of talking and arguing in the movie and sometimes the voices of the characters can drone on for a bit too long, unnecessarily lengthening the film when the next major plot-line could be brought in.

''The Wolf of Wall Street'' may not be Scorsese's best film but with a brilliant performance from DiCaprio and an all-around crazy vibe, it's another entertaining and downright hilarious movie primed to entertain.

As big of a fan of Scorsese I am, I will be the first to say I didn't enjoy this film. In fact I would have to say it is the weakest film he has done (in my opinion). I saw this film as a combination of "American Hustle", "Goodfellas", and "Casino". It's like "American Hustle" because it takes two reputable actors (Hill and DiCaprio) and makes them very unlikable. It takes the run time from "Casino". And, the ending is basically copy-paste from "Goodfellas". There are some generally funny moments, but in the end, it boils down to a lot of sex, the F word, and drugs for 3 hours. And yes I get it, they're all criminals, but this is almost taking it too far. It's as if the film is just throwing F bombs, and boobs at the screen to see what gets a laugh out of you, and that is just juvenile from a director of this stature. I am glad I saw the film and gave it a try, but, that being said I found it very drawn out and would not consider watching it again. I love you Scorsese, I really really do, and I understand that every director is entitled to one "dud film". "The Wolf of Wall Street" is that dud for me.

"The Wolf of Wall Street" is truly one of the greatest movies I have ever seen. It is oh so funny and incredibly entertaining. From nearly obnoxious characters to a vigorous dialogue, this movie really is one of the good ones. Martin Scorsese has created another absolutely outrageous, yet scary funny film. He has constructed an absolute savage movie yet somehow sticks to storyline and gives us a movie well worth watching.  The astonishing amount of drugs, alcohol, money, lovemaking and eagerness for power will keep your attention for the entire three hours. The music also plays a huge role in doing so; constantly making you cringe or tremble over the scene at hand. "The Wolf of Wall Street" is so wild and out of control, it honestly impossible to stop watching it.  With the length, sex, drugs, and profanity it is definitely not a movie to take your children to. 	All members of the cast do a wonderful job in this movie, the stand out is obviously Leonardo DiCaprio, who pretty much owns and excels in any and all scenes he is in. Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio team up again to relive the excessive lifestyle of a1980s Wall Street tycoon. The acting and direction are everything you would expect, but the story based on Jordan Belfort's memoir is a complete downer. It is a long three-hour haul for a movie with a dislikable main character. Like Scorsese's Goodfellas, we have a flawed protagonist rising to power by exploiting others. He breaks laws and gets rich while living a reckless lifestyle of drugs and prostitutes. The second half is the inevitable destruction of a man who seemingly has it all. There are enough drugs, nudity, cheap sexuality, and greed to sink a barge. This may be the most explicit movie I have seen, but it has no appeal or sensuality. The overindulgence is only off-putting and shameful. The movie has a political mission to repulse the viewer with the excessive greed of a corporate monster whom many aspire to become. It attacks the Wall Street gluttony and makes it point rather effectively. The acting from DiCaprio, Jonah Hill and the rest of the cast is impressive. In that regard, it is an admirable well-made movie. I personally get no enjoyment or learn anything in watching this unfortunate tale.
From the creators of Goodfellas and Goodfellas 2: Viva Las Vegas come Godfellas 3: Goodfellas Take Manhattan.
the scene with leonardo dicaprio high out of his mind on quaaludes is the silver lining
Enjoyment dividend falls way short for the three hour time investment. Haha see what I did there?

The Wolf on Wall Street is both entertaining, hilarious, disappointing, and always leaving you saying "I never saw that coming". Leonardo Di'Caprio was the perfect candidate to play a billionaire playboy that wants nothing else but to have fun and do whatever he wants no matter how and who it hurts. The charisma he brings to this movie draws you in. As he plays an alcoholic, billionaire playboy with a massive ego that is one of the most carefree people ever, you can't help but like him in this movie. The more you see of the true him, the more you want meet him. His life journey is both funny and sad which is why I would recommend this movie (to an older audience, some mature scenes and language).

Scorsese and Dicaprio team up again, and they deliver pretty good once again. The only reason I wouldn't give this movie a higher rating with my stars is that it is almost a little TOO much to handle. And I understand that is the point of the entire movie. Excess. Do everything to the extreme because, well you can. Dicaprio is once again awesome. It is amazing to see how Dicaprio has grown as an actor. Going from the teenage heartthrob destined to be typecasts in roles like Titanic, to becoming one of the greatest actors certainly of my generation, and honestly of all time. The guy just knows how to pick roles. Sure he has had a few duds here and there, most actors do. But he just seems to be able to fit into almost any character out there. I will be the first to say that I really am not a Jonah Hill fan. Other than Superbad, I just don't get the hype. But Hill does a really good job for his role in this movie. It is a fun movie that leaves you feeling like you are on a cocaine binge the entire time because it moves so fast, and there's so much going on. Which I am assuming is the point. The drug use is really excessive in this movie, but it is not like you were not prepared for it seeing that the opening monologue by Dicaprio is basically just him stating his love for all things narcotics. Cocaine, pills, and a little bit of crack are in this movie throughout the entire film. But my rating stays below three stars because I felt some scenes were just flat out silly. Whether they are part of the true story or not, they just didn't need to be in the film. I didn't need to see Hill's character with penis in hand masturbating in the middle of a crowded party. This movie actually plays out more like a comedy than anything else, until it gets a bit more serous towards the end when Jordan Belfort, played by Dicaprio simply tells the audience that being sober is boring and sucks. Wolf of Wall Street is a movie that you watch once, and feel that is enough. I doubt I am going to see this pop up being replayed on HBO over and over and I'm going to sit through it more than a few minutes.

Martin Scorsese delivers a black comedy that fills its prolonged run time with comprehensive characters and an engaging story that can only be defined as insane. 

"The Wolf of Wall Street" follows the story of Jordan Belfort, who quickly goes from nothing to something by becoming a stock broker. We then get to watch as he takes on the daunting life of Wall Street, and quickly becomes known as the Wolf of Wall Street. 

Let me just start by saying that this movie can only be described by using the word insane. Everything here is just crazy, and all the characters on screen have pretty much lost their minds. It's just so entertaining to see this situation and this lifestyle play out on screen, especially when many considered this movie to be unacceptable. The reason why I think that the ratings are lower than they should be is because many people felt that this movie was glorifying all of the horrible things that these stockbrokers did, and even though there is truth behind that, I still felt that this movie was still one of the best films I've seen in a while. This movie completely embraces what it is, and it will be a crazy film for many to watch. 

The reason why it took me forever to see this movie is because of the absurd long run time. It was hard to find a time in the day where I could sit down for three hours and devote all of my attention to one film, but I finally found the time. Let me tell you that it was definitely worth it, and this film didn't feel nearly as long as it's run time was. By the time the movie was over, it hadn't felt like three whole hours had past, which is really saying something. The movie manages to hold your attention during the long run time and keeps you entertained throughout. Not once did I feel like this movie was dragging on, and I actually think that the movie lasted for the perfect amount of time. I have to give this movie a lot of credit for being able to keep me focused for several hours, and I would definitely be open to re-watching this film, despite the lengthy run time. 

This movie is just filled with energy, and you really feel that throughout. The chemistry between the characters is infectious, and you can really see the enthusiasm and energy that all of them have. The actors excitement really makes this movie fun too watch, despite the obviously immoral actions that is being justified by the writers and the director. I can say that I had a ton of fun with this movie, and it is an adrenaline rush at times.

Even if you didn't like this movie, there's no denying that the acting in this movie was superb. Leonardo DiCaprio is one of the most outstanding actors in Hollywood today, and I think that he gave one of the best performances of 2013. He was maniacal yet charming in every way, and he brings so much life to a character that is so lively and animated. He manages to prove why he's one of the best actors to this day, and he was flawless. There were also plenty of notable performances from the supporting cast, as both Jonah Hill and Margot Robbie were spectacular. I actually really loved Margot Robbie, and her performance inspired me to watch more of her films. She has plenty of ingenuity and she makes her character feel so real. Jonah Hill also brings the comedy and spirit to his role, and really, everyone here did a great job.

Ultimately, this movie is a black comedy, which means it ends up justifying criminal actions and making it comical. The fact that this was based off of a true story causes this film to be treading on shallow water, and even though there isn't much repulsion shown in the tone of this movie, there are still plenty of moments to laugh about and enjoy.

This movie uses an absurd amount of sex and language to accompany its premise, and I thought that some of it was unnecessary. I actually don't really mind that stuff at this point because to me, it's just part of life and if you can handle it with maturity, then it shouldn't be a big deal. But the fact is, the overuse of this material can often make it a little bit awkward for its viewers, and this can be an uncomfortable movie to watch with others, especially if you watch it with your family. It felt like sex was used as a way to attract a slight portion of its audience, and it felt like they should've focused up on some of the more interesting aspects of the movie. 

In the end, this movie was better than I thought it could've been. It was a dark comedy that gave an extremely engrossing premise, and it captured your attention for hours. Its lengthy run time was utilized to the max, and its character development was an investment worth taking. The acting was phenomenal, and I left this movie feeling satisfied, and even a tiny bit motivated. The reason why this movie won't get a perfect score is because I think that this movie relied on an overuse of unnecessary elements,  and it justified the immoral and illegal actions in this movie without showing much repercussions for said actions. But in the end, this movie certainly is worth watching, just not with your parents.

As soon as I left the cinema I already knew that this would be one of the best movie I would have ever seen. Direction, acting and plot are flawless. Both Di Caprio's interpretation and Scorsese's directing worthed an Accademy Award or even more but unfortunately we all know how it went. I absolutely suggest you all watching it.

I've seen The Wolf of Wallstreet about 3-4 times now and it never he's boring. Marty Scorsese has created an engaging, visually stunning, highly laugh inducing comedy about a man who cares about nothing more than sex, drugs, and money (lots of it). Under any other director but Marty, this movie and its characters would've seemed pretentious. But since we have a master like Scorsese behind the camera, we end up rooting for Jordan and his jolly band of drug popping pals. And while they do treat women like the gun on the sole of your shoe, it feels appropriate considering the time they live in. This is one of Scorsese's best in recent years and I can't wait to see what he does next. I highly recommend you check it out, just not with your kids or parents.
Another Scorsese gem with another brilliant performance from DiCaprio.  A great combo that makes a film worth watching.  'Nuff said!

Wow, The Wolf on Wall Street was a no holds barred film which gave a new and refreshing light onto the subject of wall street. Martin Scorsese took so many risks with this film, from the nudity to the length, The Wolf of Wall Street was amazing and displayed true emotion.

This movie was long, at 3 hours The Wolf on Wall Street walked on a fine line of becoming full of filler, but it wasn't. When I look back on this film I couldn't cut this film down in length. For the story that they were telling every scene had a purpose, every scene needed to be in this film. 

The characters and acting in this movie were amazing. There were times where I stopped looking at the actors as actors and actually saw them as their characters. This movie brought so many actors who have fallen into averageness back into the spotlight and let them shine. The adult themes in this movie was non stop but it didn't hurt this movie at all. 

This movie was also funny, scenes in this movie seemed so realistic and worked so well for the most of the time. There was some comedy here and there where the comedy felt forced and halted the enjoyment of the drama but this was extremely rare.

In the end The Wolf on Wall Street was an excellent movie that worked in so many unique themes and subjects that it honestly felt like a new and original movie that danced to its own beat. The Wolf on Wall Street is a must see classic that will only grow overtime.

Excellent movie. Raunchy, funny, good story, great characters.  DiCaprio was perfect and likable and funny in the leading role. Some great acting from a guy who I thought was a lightweight. And Margot Robbie was smoking hot. Jonah Hill was hilarious, as was Matthew McConaughey. Based on a true story of a stock broker who builds a financial empire, then gets knocked down by the FBI. One of those movies I can watch over and over for an enjoyable 2 hour ride.

The main idea behind this one was probably to make the most hollow film ever created. I believe they mostly have succeeded in that goal, so two stars for that.

Wolf of Wall Street is a marvelous film about greed. From a visual and storytelling standpoint Scorcese is great. But it would not be the same without DiCaprio's Oscar worthy performance

The constant theme of Martin Scorsese's best work are the temptations of the flesh, never more aptly seen than though the prism of real-life subjects.  He's explored this through Jake LaMotta, Howard Hughes, Henry Hill and Jesus Christ, but in his new film The Wolf of Wall Street, Jordan Belfort may have the most savage appetite of them all.  Here, Scorsese turns his camera to the greed and avarice of the stock market boom of the late 80s that he sees in almost the same way as his great film Goodfellas, with a kid from the middle class who finds a short-route to riches and unapologetically enjoys the anything-goes lifestyle.  He wants anything and everything and gets it, no matter what.  Then, as Scorsese's subjects always do, must suffer for it.  Jordan races through life as fast as he can, acquiring anything and everything he can get his hands on.  Anything?  How about his own yacht with a helipad?  Of course, you'll need a helicopter to go along with it.

Like Goodfellas, which followed the personal real-life story of an outsider into the world of New York gangsters, The Wolf of Wall Street follows the rise and fall of Jordan Belfort, who narrates his own story with the energy of a runaway bullet train.  At 22, he is a nice kid from the middle class who gets a job with a legendary Wall Street firm L.J. Rothchild under the tutelage of Mark Hanna (Matthew McConaughey) a wiry drug-addict who not only trains the kid, but lets him in on the secrets of quick success.  "The name of the game," he tells Jordan," is moving the money from the client's pocket to your pocket."  This is a mantra that Jordan takes to heart, even if the client doesn't make a dime.

Then, only weeks after getting the job, Rothchild hits a brick wall on October 19th, 1987 - Black Monday - forcing the grand old lady to close its doors after 90 years.  Without a job, he starts from the bottom at the only firm that will hire him - a meager penny-stock firm that works out of an auto parts garage.  Jordan makes himself a superstar by proving how easy it is to scam the client to make money fast.  He takes over the business, building it from penny stocks to Blue Chips to IPOs born on the backs of screwing their clients.  To his surprise, he finds a small patch of money hungry brokers ready to follow his lead.  Most visible is a pudgy Jewish kid named Donnie (Jonah Hill) who becomes his right arm. Donnie is a glutinous yin to Jordan's yang, an otherwise nice Jewish kid who tries to throw off that moniker by dressing as WASP-like as he can.

In no time Jordan has turned the tiny boiler room brokerage firm into Stratton Oakmont, an operation built on crooked investments from which flows money, money, money leading to mountains of drugs, rooms full of naked women, and every expensive toy under the sun.  He feels guilty about nothing, taking Gordon Gekko's mantra of "Greed is Good" and making it into a religious sacrament.  Jordan is a modern-day Caligula, a Roman Emperor who makes no apologies for his gross avarice, his drug addiction, his sex addiction or any other morally reprehensible machination that allowed him to get it.  In no time at all he has be biggest house, the biggest boat, the best sports car, the fastest plane, and mounds and mounds of drugs.  He even trades in his supportive wife ("How I Met Your Mother"'s Cristin Milioti) for a gorgeous blonde trophy wife (Naomi Robbie).

In our minds, possibly not to Jordan, there is always the dread that the party will come to an end.  We feel that, but Jordan constantly skirts disaster, especially late in the film when he desperately needs to get to Switzerland and takes his own boat instead of a plane.  The plane explodes in mid-air and Jordan comes to believe that he may be invincible.  We feel that too, even when a boy scout FBI agent (Kyle Chandler) start snooping around Jordan's books.  The scene at sea, incidentally, is a not-so-thinly veiled call-back to DiCaprio's role in Titanic when his boat is caught in a violent storm and it looks like The King of the World won't make it out of this one either.

The rhythm of the film is familiar to anyone who has seen Scorsese's films before, what is amazing is that it's always infectious.  We know that what Jordan and Donnie are doing is morally reprehensible, but there is something in the attractiveness of their behavior that makes us privately hope that they won't get caught.  In our own way we like these guys, and that may come from our familiarity with their other films.  DiCaprio, in particular, turns in his very best performance, throwing away his good-guy image as a man who lives by appetite alone.  There are notes here that DiCaprio has never been able to display.  Yes, he's good looking, but he isn't afraid to look like a jerk.  Here he is able to display his talent for slapstick in a scene in which Jordan ingests a 15 year-old Quaalude that sends his body into a fit very close to cerebral palsy.  That's no good when he desperately needs to get to his car to stop Donnie from making a fatal mistake.  What is surprising is that this scene is played for laughs and it works!

This is a movie made up of two or three dozen perfect moments like that.  Overall it's energy is charged by the pacing and by DiCaprio's in-your-face narration.  This is a raunchy, messy, but ultimately exciting film about one guy who desires everything and gets it.  If it seems a bit too long, that's only because it is playing to the theme of wretched excess.  The end of the film sends Jordan on a toboggan slide that seems somewhat inevitable, causing his reign as king of the world to end with a whimper instead of a bang.  Does he learn a lesson from all his sins of lust and greed?  What do you think?

It's a hell of a fun ride, but that's about it. If you're expecting some rich character study or life lesson you won't find it here. That being said, I don't see this move as condoning the acts of Belfort either. It's merely a surface level look in to a world most of us won't ever get a better look at.

Martin Scorsese gets an A+ in the department of directing his cast. He made Leonardo Le Crappio give me Scarface flashbacks. He made Jonah Hill look like prime Sylvester Stallone. The only actor who I'm convinced brought his own superb raw talent to the room and wouldn't have needed is Matthew McConaughey as Mark Hanna. Unfortunately, his role is so painfully brief. But I could've listened to him talk about business and drugs for my entire life and involuntarily orgasm and regular intervals he was so fucking good. Strange of me to compliment Mr. Shirtless in Space so highly.
Terence Winter gets an A- in the dialogue gig. Which is especially impressive considering this is his only movie that matters for shits. I would think he would already be locked to do more movies based on this performance. Unfortunately, he does not get quite a high grade for storytelling. We're following a protagonist who is a slimy scumbag. Now, normally, I'd just immediately chop off your head right there. But you did a smart thing and show that Leo got into this at a relatively young age. So now there's a sense of sympathy for this guy amidst all his heinous acts. You've got two options from this point: You can either tell a redemption story or a fall from grace story. They went for the fall from grace option. Unfortunately, in order to tell a fall from grace story, they must...fall from grace. They need somewhere to fall from. And the first thing, second thing, and everything you show us, is him being a slimy, womanizing, drug-addicted criminal. So you got nothing. Every time he considers cleaning up his act, he gets right back to business as usual. The time he actually goes sober for two years has two major sins: First, it's not the resolution of the movie. Second: It's skipped over in under a minute. So instead of giving us the satisfaction of knowing he made it out and that we can get out, he just winds up going to prison, losing his kid....and the last thing you show us is him, ugh, doing the "sell me this pen" routine? Yeah, that, that's definitely satisfying. We just invested 3 hours in your movie so we could know that he taught people how to sell pens. Great lessons.
And yes, Scorsese made the best out of these jabroonis, but casting director Ellen Lewis ought to be fired for deciding that Leonardo Le Crappio and Jonah Hill were good casting decisions for this movie. Have we not fallen far from the days of Al Pacino and Robert DeNiro. Minor complaint. She's done a lot of other great movies so who gives a shit.
Editor Thelma Schoonmaker, who has done other classics, also puts on a firing-worthy performance. From moments of incoherency and decision making with absolutely zero logic - something you would expect would be extinct in something as professional and something with as much money in it as Hollywood - to moments of thematic incorrectness - moments where the story telling would be helped if sequences were re-arranged. Also, she allowed Martin Scorsese to pressure her into a three hour movie. Who in the world decided to make this a 3 hour movie? Who deserves to be fired? Is it the producer? Is it one of the other four producers? Is it the editor? Is it Scorsese? Just because it's a book doesn't mean it has to be this long. Just because Scarface had similar ideas doesn't mean this needs to be 3 hours. This story begs for 105 minutes, and could be told in 90. What we have are some 8-12 unneeded story events and dozens of repetitive scenes - how many times do I need to look at a room with a bunch of naked people mindlessly fucking and crack on the table before I get the point? Oh, speaking of hammering things into our head - a narrator? In 2013? Are you kidding me? And hey, it's one thing already when the narrator makes me want to send Martin Scorsese, the ultimate film professor, back to film school, because he's breaking the most basic film rule of all time: show don't tell...and it's an entirely different thing when Leonardo Le Crappio and his filthy mug are looking at me and explaining to me what an "IPO" is, when the audience could very well figure it out - especially when you're limiting your audience to very aged and experience consumers with material making this what should be an X-Rated movie if the MPAA had any testicles.
A film with great raw attributes - dialogue, directing, acting, basic human relations - is bogged down into just a "pretty good" movie by its tremendous flaws - runtime, direction, casting, story, editing, repetition. B-

It was one of the most controversial and talked-about films of the year, and marked Scorsese and DiCaprio's most unhinged collaboration yet. I dreaded its infamously excessive run time (close to 3 hours), but I was thankful to have never been bored at any point. Wolf Of Wall Street is a slickly made, well written, exuberantly acted piece of cinematic dynamite. I really can't think of a more fitting metaphor than that. It's a tale of greed, back-stabbing, debauchery and the ultimate consequences of a person's selfish actions. DiCaprio takes on arguably his most energetic and downright hilarious role, and instils a blood-hungry savage stock broker with charisma, bravado and, most surprisingly of all, likeability. In less capable hands our hero may have emerged as a hammy, one-dimensional jerk with no way to go but further and further over the top, but when he hits his low points you feel genuinely sorry for him. The first hour is a riotous and borderline hallucinatory journey into the life of a man with one mission: Make as much money as quickly as possible. From the beginning, with his meteoric rise to success, the celebrations, the friends, the relationships, it's clear it's all going to go badly wrong. Even when it's not throwing drug-fuelled parties at us, it manages never to become sluggish, but it runs far too long, and could have benefited from losing 30 minutes, largely with the shortening of some scenes which prattle on excessively. But ironically enough, excessive is the perfect word to describe the film. It has many stand-out scenes, a furious energy, particularly in the first half, boasts a central performance that was rightly acclaimed, and offers up a tonne of fun while also serving as a stark reminder that the higher the climb, the more painful the fall.

We've all seen movies about shysters, guys who can talk you out of your last dollar, whose motto is never give a sucker an even break. Most of these movies have a moral. The scam artist finally gets his. The chickens come home to roost, and the families who've been bilked out of their life savings get to glower down at their tormentor, now in chains, thanks to the intrepid detective, presented as a hero. 

Not this movie. The Wolf of Wall Street builds his little gang of fast-talkers, in whose hands a telephone is but an instrument to rob you blind. The con treats his tribe as family; they weep with gratitude as he big-heartedly helps them on their way towards Mercedes and Bentleys and homes in The Hamptons. There's no Godfather here. No one is dispatched to the bathtub to take their own life or pressured to join the fun by waking up to a horse's head. Everyone has fun here. And the detective who (sort of) brings him down is presented as a hardworking dupe, a sad-sack clock-puncher whose reward for his accomplishment is a daily subway ride amongst a sea of tired and lonely faces. In this movie, the con is stripped of a few of his toys, survives with his health and good humor intact, and moves abroad to once again build his little empire of crooks. Ever hear the Elton John song "Mona Lisas and Mad Hatters."? It came to mind here: "sons of bankers, sons of lawyers who turn around and say good morning to the night." Well, happily, movies this nihilistic nature weren't popular when Martin Scorsese was a young man choosing a trade. Why would a bright young man choose film-making, which requires study, patience, hard work and early failures, when you can trick honest people out of their money and get away with it?

Perhaps one reason why this movie struck such a poor note with me is that I have many friends in former USSR states, states now run by cons, by grifters and crooks, and my young friends there have grown up in a world thinking that that's simply how things are done. I think that sucks.

ScorLeo give us yet another elongated biopic, this time about rampant materialism and greed of 80's Wall Street, and the rise and fall of relentless go-getter and scam artist Jordan Belfort. Independent funders let Scosese run wild on a loose leash, allowing him to tell this excoriating orgy of drug-fueled capitalist overindulgence without hindrance from upper-brass. And the end result is an incredible three-hour-long free for all of midget tossing, Lambo crashing, Quaalude popping and orgy hosting that didn't skimp on the necessary Scosese-ness. If you offend easily, The Wolf of Wall Street will spit you out in a heartbeat. Such is the insanity of this film's delivery, and such is the brilliance of Leonardo DiCaprio's performance as the charismatic lead, that it's all too easy to get swept away in the adrenalin rush and not realize what an impressive film this is.

Martin Scorsese hasn't made many comedies in his long career. Oh sure, he has made some of the all time great gangster and crime films - of this have no doubt. Yet the list of comedies grows short with only the acidic The King of Comedy (1983) coming to mind. The current vogue among comedies are raunchy with a personal touch. The Wolf of Wall Street uses Scorsese's favorite actor of late Leonardo DiCaprio in a comedic setting. It shows the actor's and director's relationship has come full circle. From the early dramas like Gangs of New York (2002) or The Aviator (2004), to the trust it takes to makes a comedy. It is a risk for a legendary director to make a comedy since he will forever be known for his dramas. The Wolf of Wall Street fails if audience members view it as a cautionary tale of greed and lust. It works better if viewed as a satire or raunchy tall tale. While not Scorsese's best film, it does draw strong biographical parallels to Goodfellas (1990) in its storyline. Above all, The Wolf of Wall Street is a legacy film built by Scorsese to have fun and to flex his directorial muscles by doing comedy in the twilight of his career.

The Wolf of Wall Street is both a biographical tale and a comedy rolled into one film. Directed and Produced by Martin Scorsese The Wolf of Wall Street tells the story of Jordan Belfort who made his highly successful career as a criminalistics stock broker and businessman until the law comes crashing down on him. Scorsese demonstrates the ridiculous antics of Belfort in a graphic and extremely detailed way that is both over the top and entertaining to watch. This film is a must see due to the interesting was Belfort is demontrated as an "antihero". No matter how much you want the protagonist to win, you know he is a bad person. This antihero status played by DiCaprio makes the film extremely interesting no matter how it ends. DiCaprio plays the role perfectly aided by the outrageous Jonah Hill this film is both hilarious and quite dark at the same time.

It's another outstanding film from Scorsese that this time delivers such a high in comedic value that you'd think him a master of comedy rather than Drama. The film benefits greatly from DiCaprio's addition to his list of outstanding performances as well as some solid acting from Hill and the rest of the cast. What I can take a shot at in this film however, is Scorsese's notable rhythm that he seems to be imitating in many films that both stamps this film Scorsese's and also makes it a bit of too familiar in themes similar to GoodFellas and narrating similar to a large number of his films. Nonetheless it is an excellent film, though a bit overly graphic and loses a bit of fans as being such. (84%)

An excellent movie anchored superbly by the the performances of the leads (and the supporting cast!) and direction that is as utterly competent as you'd expect. 

Problem is I feel the story would occasionally get lost in itself. Not that it was hard to follow, the pacing was in fact on point, but it squeezes in many details that don't pay off and the length is padded more than it needs. Its a character study, a black comedy and a crime drama that avoids most cliches and it'd be impossible to call it derivative. Debauchery abounds, and this movie is definitely *not* about the hardworking 'good guy' FBI agents who end up taking down the corrupt and morally bankrupt main character. Their investigation is only portrayed as incidental to Jordan's shenanigans. But this isn't because Jordan is a PROtagonist, oh no. Its hard to like him but you probably will not hate him (although you would have cause to) since, unlike some movies in this vein, he pays dearly for all of his excesses, and it turns out he's not quite the mastermind he pretends. Where other movies would have the smooth-customer exec pulling double-crosses and cons to stay ahead of the cops, Jordan is a drugged-out salesman scrambling to hold his 'empire' together and failing at almost every turn, usually due to his own doings or those of his 'friends.' But you can't really feel pity for him either. All in all the character is fully realized and you do want to see his plight through for his sake, no matter how you feel about him.

Jordan also narrates his journey in the 'speak to the camera as I move through the scene' style and in voice-over. Normally I find this a bit of a lazy move, especially when its throughout the movie, but it gets played with here to some good effect. It still feels a bit like Scorcese is treating the audience as dumb, and maybe... just maybe that's the point. Jordan is after all a salesman and by letting him address the audience directly you can experience him trying to 'sell' himself and his story. Maybe he is trying to play us for suckers as he does everyone else. So it works but it still sticks out and hampers my overall opinion of the film. 

So while it doesn't hit every single note right, the entire symphony works really well and DiCaprio is once again proving that the Academy Awards are a farce. The charisma this guy can bring to the screen

I don't see the appeal of this movie. It's not all that funny. Almost every "joke" it tries to make is a crass discussion about sex. It was obvious every time it was trying to make a joke because they had proper comedic timing and execution, but it didn't make me laugh. Even when I forced myself to smile in order to see if that made me more willing to laugh, I couldn't. I only genuinely found it funny when Donnie was having a conversation about marrying his cousin, and during a particularly outrageous drug trip.

The story got very repetitive at times. It repeated the same three things in many ways without really raising the stakes or switching things up at all. Jordan makes lots of money, has lots of sex, and does a lot of drugs. I got that; it would have been cool to show more about how this affected his personal life. When it came to the business aspect, I would have appreciated more detail about the inner workings of the stock market. Instead the movie just kept saying how rich the characters got. In the beginning, we get to see actual expansion of the company and a measurable change in the wealth of the characters, but this got boring very fast. Seeing the details of each scheme would have made things more interesting, but the main problem is that they get so rich at one point that any other money they earn doesn't seem to make a difference anymore. And this point comes fairly early on in the movie. This makes the 3-hour runtime feel unnecessary; I think a lot of scenes could have been cut and we would still have understood how insane Jordan's life was. The final act when his life starts to fall apart is easily the most compelling. 

I just like seeing Jordan Belfort as a character more than anything. He goes through a massive amount of growth and change in his attitude and behavior, and this is phenomenally portrayed by DiCaprio. All the actors did great, but this was an Oscar-worthy performance by him. He delivers each line with a sense of sincerity and makes it seem like every outrageous stunt Belfort pulls off is natural. Even when I got sick of hearing "fuck" and other vulgarity spewed every other second, I never got tired of watching Jordan.

Overall, great movie. People who take the film to seriously should relax, it kept you on your feet the whole time, engaged, and by the end of it it'll have you reflecting on Belfort's life...I know I found myself on Google trying to learn more.

The fact that Scorsese and the cast can keep you completely entertained for 3 hours is amazing, and then the story and the humour behind it just makes it one of the best movies I've ever seen. The acting is on point, and features a rookie performance from upcoming powerhouse actress Margot Robbie, and a varsity performance from the one and only Leonardo DeCaprio. The film is an instant classic.
incredible.  well acted and directed

Martin Scorsese has done it again! This film is nothing short of brilliant! I loved this movie, I thought it was funny and crazy. I'm not going to spend too much time going into detail on how everybody did because everyone was great in the movie. Everything in this movie is crazy and fun. I thought they could've toned done the sexual content and nudity a little bit though. This movie is a great depiction on the life of Jordan Belfort and how crazy he got with his money and his life. Go watch this movie in theaters, it's worth your time and money. 

The Wolf of Wall Street: 4.5/5 stars
it was good but could have been cut down... lost interest in parts of the movie because all I started to hear was, "blah blah blah".
Fantastic sets and costumes and a lovely view of the late 80s an era I had no experience of before the movie. Definitely 18 rated, enjoyed it and I'd probably watch it again. Defo a blokes movie!

Martin Scorsese knows how to direct these swindlers films with male protagonists, here projected us a riskier proposal, that's to say more crazy, but that leaves us a weird feeling because the script promise too much and although the film is quite long, leaves us with some unfinished scenes and other unnecessary. 8/10

"El Lobo de Wall Street". Combinación de humor sarcástico ofensivo, drama y película biográfica, muestra un escenario cómico y duro sobre cómo funciona un inversionista cuando no tiene un control emocional sobre el dinero, que al final da una lección importante sobre el mismo. A very eccentric film featuring vibrant characters, a witty script, and suitably outlandish performances, The Wolf of Wall Street may be a tad indulgent that lacks emotional resonance, but nonetheless is a wild, funny, and entertaining ride under the sure-handed direction of Martin Scorsese.

The Wolf of Wall Street stars a very ambitious Leonardo Dicaprio and a hilarious Jonah Hill. The story follows stock broker Jordan Belfort who starts out small but through many scams of penny stocks he makes it to the big leagues and makes millions of dollars. To start, the best parts about this movie are the actors, the story, and how fun this movie really is. Leonardo Dicaprio and Jonah Hill give really top notch performances, I feel that the performances they gave were their best. Margot Robbie was really good and for the short time Matthew McConaughy was on screen he did really good too. The setting of the movie was beautiful no matter where they were and it was just really pleasant to look at. The ambition that all these characters have is really inspiring but maybe not for the right reason because the characters are really slimy. The mishaps that Jordan encounters are pretty fun to watch main because of how funny they are, especially the part when he really overdoses on drugs with Donnie to the point where they can't move. I hate to say it but to see this guy fall from grace was pretty satisfying. He was just a really unlikable person the way he took money from other people for his own benefit and used it on drugs and hookers which I mean was fun to watch in a movie but thinking how this really happened is frustrating. The low points of this movie seemed to happen whenever he came in contact with the Feds because the movie seemed to slow down at parts where Kyle Chandler's character came on screen except for the first time he met with Jordan. Another problem I had is the editing of the movie was not the best. There were parts where a scene would just zip too quickly in the middle of a conversation and it was distracting. The Wolf of Wall Street had some awesome performances, a great story that stays true to material, a great cast, lots of funny and fun parts too enjoy. A-

Martin Scorsese delivers a self-aware tale of life about the life of the one percent, and is a representation of the times. the dialogues and characters are hilariously and along with the incredible performances of actors like DiCaprio and Jonah Hill. However the movie stretches a tad too long with the 3 hour run time the film does not escalate and the ending is a little under-whelming.

Leonardo is officially the new De Niro as can be seen in most Scorsese films these days. However, this piece isn't criminal mobster related as seen in previous Scorsese greatness. They are Wall Street criminals instead!

This is one of my favorite films of all time! Leonardo DiCaprio's performance in this is one of my favorites and I think will go down as an all time classic. Martin Scorsese has really done it again. It really isn't fair when Scorsese and Leo team up together. Jonah Hill is incredible and is hilarious. We get the break out star Margot Robbie who is amazing. This movie is 3 hours long but you will not feel it. I have watched this movie at least 10 times and never feel the run time and would honestly watch another hour if possible. It is possibly the funniest movie I have ever seen while still being a drama. I cannot exaggerate how great this movie is. DiCaprio gives the best performance of his career and delivers some of the most quotable lines of the decade. Scorsese has an obsession with making movies about self-destructive men and Jordan Belfort is nothing if not self-destructive. He takes drugs a lot, he drinks a lot, he has sex with hot models a lot - Belfort lives everything in excess. Which is what this movie is about - the American dream gone haywire. I have never really seen a movie like this one before. It really does push the limits of what a movie can get away with and still retain an R rating, but that's what it makes it great. Besides DiCaprio, Jonah Hill and Margot Robbie also give great performances that compliment Belfort's excessive lifestyle.
Excellent movie, showing the corruption within wall street, and the pitfalls of drug abuse.

The Wolf of Wall Street is incredibly overrated. Its satire comedic style is funny in places but is quite often mindlessly overdone. It appears to be sophisticated but more often than not its screaming, shouting, drugs, alcohol and hookers. It lacks substance and the story is incredibly hollow. The performances on offer were to the highest quality, especially the terrific Leonardo DiCaprio yet this was was done by an hugely dragged out plot which was quite plainly, lacklustre. A 3 hour movie could have been told in 1 and a half and would of been far more bearable than some of the trashy scenes and repetitive speeches. It is a original idea and in places its genuinely funny but overall its not worth its plaudits.

I have seen a few Scorcese films and he seriously must be the most overrated director ever.  I wanted to see this film simply because of the subject matter, however the semi decent story becomes lost under a deluge of bad language, mostly f words.  Dicaprio is very good in the lead role as Belfort who comes across as a total dick with more money than sense.  Overall though the script is pretty poor and the film is way too long.

Not just one of my favorite movies of 2013, but also my favorite acting performances.  Leo was robbed of the Oscar he so rightfully deserved, and so was Scorsese. This great film has an excess of drug use, nudity, and language to desensitiz the audience. Just remember that this is a Martin Scorsese film, and like most of his films, it is almost 3 hours long. Hit play and enjoy a great film of the rise and fall of, let's face it, a grade "A" asshole.
The rise and fall of an unorthodox stock broker. Leonardo DiCaprio is turning into a very fine actor!

A blend of biography/comedy/crime/drama, this Martin Scorsese directed movie features exceptional performances in an interesting (but very sex and drugs heavy) story about Jordan Belfort's life in Wall Street.

I find no reason to not give this movie the perfect score. It's incredibly smart and funny, superbly acted and definitely engaging throughout the whole three hours. All of those who complain about the movie "worshiping excess and criminal behavior" should remember that the main purpose of a film is to entertain, not to pursue social or moral causes. I've finally seen this film just to get what all the fuss is about. There is a good half an hour that should have been cut out from the film. Particularly the party and orgy sequences. Most of the time I was like, yes I get it, move on. I found it far too long. It also didn't help that couldn't care less about what happens to the characters because I hated every last one of them. BUT!!! Did I find the film funny? Yes I did. Was Leonardo DiCaprio's performance good? Yes it was.
Den bliver bedre jo mere man tænker over den.

1 and a half hours worth of plot stretched boringly into 3 hours. If we talk about the 3-act structure, act 2 doesn't begin until 2 hours in, and there isn't really an act 3 at all. The first 2 hours are basically a GTA style montage with nothing actually happening to advance the story. Well made, has it's moments, but just too damn long.

There are many positives in this film, some of these are: the comedy in the film is great, the story progressed really well and the acting was great. Certain parts of the film stand out to me as great comedic moments, for example: the whole scene where he is trying to get to his car when he is high was brilliant and also all the 5 seconds with Matthew McConaughey were absolute gold. Also the story progression was good from starting from nothing to having it all, was the best part of the film in my opinion and the ending was satisfying. Finally all the acting in the movie was great especially Leonardo DiCaprio's performance from his turn of a good man who didn't do drugs to basically a massive arsehole but he made that look good. There are also a few small negatives; one of them is the over use of nudity in this film. I think in the film it was understandable why there was so much nudity, but it seemed that it was just too over the top and got ridiculous in some places. Another negative is, the story as a whole was slightly predictable and even before seeing it I had a rough guess of how the movie would progress; start at the bottom and work his way up the chain and become really rich, I thought this would be about half the film and the rest is everything falling apart and then somehow he cleans up his act. Even though that description is quite general I thought that as that is pretty much exactly how it played out was slightly annoying.

The Wolf of Wall Street is a modern Shakespearian tragedy. Leo knocks his performance out of the park and keeps my attention better than most others could for the near three hour run time. Leo even makes you sympathize with him despite the fact he is playing one of the most sleazy and unlikeable criminals of our time. Leo's performance is aided by Jonah Hill in his character role as comedic sidekick. Margo Robbie destroys her role with insane passion and direct dialogue to the point that I will see whatever she stars in next. 

In typical biopic fashion, this movie follows the events of its central character's life. Many events are only loosely tied together their overall goal being to show the rise and fall of Jordan Belfort. This works well enough to tell the story, but makes it easy to forget little bits of subplot here and there. 

The Wolf of Wall Street shines through the fog as a Scorsese and Leo film first and foremost, and is as good as the sum of its parts. You'll see their typical product on screen, which won't blow your mind, but will be a hell of a good time (despite the typical bad cuts Scorsese allows in his film).

Flirting with greatness, heady social satire and a statement on human greed, Wolf of Wall Street doesn't quite hit that mark. 

Make no mistake, the performance by Leonardo Dicaprio was electric and Jonah Hill proved a more than adequate first mate, the films problems are in indulgence that comes off as unnecessary, and at times almost boring. 

Take out half the drugs and pornography and this film might even hold some authentic weight as an exploration of the psyche of a wall Street mogul, while cutting down on an excessive 3 hour run time. 

It's all in good fun, and its certainly entertaining to say the least but I can't help but feel rather than satirizing or even exploring the debauchery, Scorcese and his film are celebrating it. 

Still, slick, realistic dialogue, a well developed sound track, consistent tone and nonstop energy give The Wolf of Wall Street plenty of life and legs. You just have to overlook the numerous bad editing cuts, and at times poor pacing and inefficient storytelling and you'll have a great time. 

But this film is certainly not for everyone.

A little too focused on outlandishness and vulgarity, I still found the Wolf of Wall Street quite enjoyable, thanks to the brilliant performances, some humorous moments, and a generally captivating story.

It takes a lot to ring in the title of, "one of the most messed up movies I've ever seen," but this dark comedy (which surprisingly brings out some of Scorsese and DiCaprio's best) deserves that title in full.

Martin Scorsese always brings out the best in DiCaprio. What a great performance. What hurt this film was the sex. I mean what was the point of showing endless amounts of debauchery and drug use? Talk about beating a dead horse!

If you have not already seen The Wolf of Wall Street, I would add it to your list of must see movies. An account of real life events through the eyes of Jordan Belfort, The Wolf of Wall Street, has a good balance of heavy drama and dark humor sprouting from the excess drugs, sex, and money of Wall Street. Possibly one of the best qualities of this movie is the seamless storytelling, nothing is left out. Along with this, the narration by Leonardo DiCaprio is magnificent. The supporting characters as well are spot on, the waspy Donnie Azoff (Jonah Hill) provides not only humorous relief but depth into the poisonous effects of greed. Through the movie we watch as the 22 year old Belfort metamorphoses from an ambitious youngster ready to make his mark on the world to a multimillionaire poisoned by greed and copious amounts of Quaaludes and Cocaine.
Didn't care for it. Long winded and overrated.

As an aside, I thought that DiCaprio and Jonah Hill both did a great job with their characters.
