Martin Scorsese directs the Wolf of Wall Street which depicts the rise and fall of a corrupt stock broker. Many of Scorsese films start off with showing you how great crime can pay and how greed, lust and corruption can tear it all apart leading to heartbreak and misery and no film does this better than Goodfellas. In Wolf of Wall Street tries to be the Goodfellas of the New York stock exchange world. In Goodfellas you rooted for the villains and you wanted to be a gangster, and he aims for this same effect for the corrupt Wall Street broker played by Dicaprio. Ultimately he fails, and the movie in the good years goes on too long and really does not have enough variation to it. The support characters aside from Hill are not memorable at all and I couldn't careless what happened to them, but when you saw Sorvino and Dinero go to prison in Goodfellas you were crushed. The fall in Wall Street was just mundane and stereotypical. Dicaprio was fine, but many times I felt I could have been more inspired by his pep talks and I never really routed for him. Overall Wolf of Wall-street takes too long to get to the point and does not have strong enough characters to carry you on the emotional roller coaster that Scorsese has taken us in his previous epic masterpieces.

Totally worth it's three hour running time. DiCaprio and Hill's performances are amazing. Scorsese hits the nail on the head and somehow made a film about such horrible people the most fun I've had watching a movie.

"SEX, DRUGS AND STOCK EXCHANGE"  

- 'The Wolf of Wall Street' is a 2013 satire by director Martin Scorsese (Taxi Driver, The Departed), based upon the memoirs of Jordan Belfort. It is also the fifth film where Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio (Titanic, Inception) work together. The story gives us viewers a look behind the scenes of a stockbroker company, where drugs, money and decadency are primal and will eventually lead to a downfall. I enjoyed the film a lot. Some parts where really funny, and I must praise DiCaprio for his brilliant performance. Also starring Jonah Hill (Superbad, This is the End), Matthew McConaughey (Dallas Buyers Club, Amistad) and Margot Robbie. Want to make easy money?

Jordan Belfort (DiCaprio) is an ambitious young man when he joins the established Wall Street firm LF Rothschild. His boss (McConaughey) advises him to adapt a life of sex and drugs in order to succeed in the world of stock exchange. Unfortunately, Jordan soon loses his job because of bankruptcy as a result of Black Monday. In his next job Belfort learns how to earn money due to commissions in penny stocks.  As a result he decides to start his own stock exchange business with the help from his neighbor Donnie Azof (Hill). In the following years the firm expands and both men are adapt the decadent lifestyle of sex and drugs. But will their luck remain unchanged?
Awesome film, DiCaprio's best film yet.

One of, if not Leonardo DiCaprio finest hour. As for the film, my personal opinion is it's up there with some of the greats. There are some absolutely funny scenes at times. Very well written story, which I'm sure is very realistic for the era.

Although bolstered by a traditionally strong DeCaprio performance, the Wolf Of Wall Street is ultimately to much of a spectacle for my taste. I admire both DiCaprio and Hill's ability to transform their characters but this transformation is one I neither wanted to see or understand. The fact is, Belfort was and still is an asshole and a criminal, and not a sorry one at that. This makes the story ultimately un-redeeming and without some redemption, I find it impossible to watch Leo snort cocaine and hire strippers for three hours. Ultimately a miss for both Scorsese and DiCaprio, the latter of which is going to have to consider some different partnerships and film choices if he ever plans on winning an Oscar and not just playing at one.

A must-see movie for any investor or anyone interested in investing. It is a bit dirty but the lessons are valuable. I know because I have been investing in the stock market for 25 years.

The lessons you should lean from this movie are: 
1. Nobody knows where the stock market will go tomorrow so all those "experts" are lying. 
2. Stock brokers only care about selling you a trade because they only make money off trade commissions. They don't care if you buy or sell just as long as you trade something. They do not have your best interest in mind, just their best interest. So when they say they know a stock will go up, they are lying. 
3. Beware of the pump-and-dump scam where a broker pups of the price of a low volume stock, usually on the pink sheets. Then they sell all of their stock which forces the price of the stock to dump.

Review:
I really enjoyed this epic movie which keeps you on the end of your seat from beginning to end. Although the film is about serious issues, there is some really funny scenes, especially between DiCaprio and Hill who had great chemistry. The storyline goes from one extreme to the next, which is what made it hard to believe that it was based on a true story. The amount of money that the traders go through is ridiculous and the whole care free attitude had to come to a holt at some point. At nearly 3 hours long, the director done well to keep the movie interesting and a joy to watch. I never thought that I would say this, but it is in the same class as the original Wall Street which was a tough act to follow. A Great Watch!

Round-Up:
DiCaprio really showed that he is a top class actor with his performance in this movie. He really needed to dig deep to make this character believable because of the amount of drugs, cash and women that him and his friends went through, under the eyes of the law. Jonah Hill was an excellent choice to play DiCaprio's partner in crime who also showed that a different side to his acting skills. Even Matthew McConaughey was brilliant, with his weird expressions and phrases which were a great way to kick off the movie. Anyway, it's very hard to find anything wrong with this film, although some of the speeches on the microphone did drag on, but that's just me being picky. Its  definitely worth a watch!

Director Martin Scorsese comes back with another BIG HIT!!!! He is everywhere with this movie, The Wolf of Wall Street (2013). It was entertaining and it was something new that an audience member like me would like to see, with a good handful of Popcorn, A Glass of GingerAle, and a couple of Junior Mints. For the Soundtrack, there were many Artists (Various Artists) that gave it their all to make The Wolf of Wall Street 5 Stars. Personally, I felt like the music was perfectly placed throughout the movie when it came to the Sex, the Drugs, and the Money. The Editor, Thelma Schoonmaker did a wonderful job with the overlaying of the score to the Motion Picture. Congrats to all of you! I give you my applaud, to the Actors, especially the Actresses, the Director, the Writers, the Editors, and the Various Artists that led The Wolf of Wall Street to be a 5 Star Motion Picture. As always, Martin Scorsese is a legendary director among many in the Streets of Hollywood. He brings his game to the tables and that is what makes him the Man of Movies. My favorite Actor Leonardo DiCaprio did a splendid job on bringing us the true reality of what it truly means to bring the Sex, the Drugs, and the Money.

The Wolf of Wall Street suffers from the same problem Jordan Belfort experiences: Excess.  It's a captivating movie that just feels too exhausting to finish.  You end up counting the number of minutes that could have been saved (like the Jonah fish scene, many awkward pauses, jokes that don't really need to be drawn out) and expect the film to be a Judd Apatow production, versus really enjoying the story.  It also feels way too biased towards portraying Belfort as a hero in the film.  It just feels too inorganic.  That said, it was interesting to see the story play out, and Leo is pretty good ranging from his different phases (although really people, it's so "Oscar set" but it doesn't feel like it's anything different from DiCaprio before.  Why should he win just because he has done work like this in the past, versus doing something bold and interesting?)  The rest of the ensemble, while fun (like Hill, Reiner, Favreau, etc) just really doesn't feel more than caricatures, and even worse than American Hustle since it was clear they weren't supposes to be.  Then there are the obvious plot problems.  If people know they are in a pump and dump scheme, wouldn't they catch on to Belfort?  Wouldn't the investors stop investing?  I guess it's not a bad movie, it's more an overdrawn, Oscar bait film that feels too biased for it's own good.

Martin Scorsese's directorial style has never been more fitting, in The Wolf Of Wall Street his energetic sweeping camera movements follow the dirty and lively lifestyle of the wolf, as well as his stockbrokers and his insane parties. What really did it for me was DiCaprio's moments where he speaks to the camera, breaking the fourth wall explaining what is going on, it's like a direct invitation into the world of Belfort's dirty work. 

Indulging in excess, bad behaviour and general debauchery, this Oscar nominated movie boasts sharp writing and a phenomenal cast full of talent. They are impeccable delivering perfect performances, DiCaprio is at his A-game as is Jonah Hill too, plus Margot Robbie, P.J. Byrne and Cristin Milioti are spectacular supporting cast actors who shine as bright as their lead star. Best of all, this movie has a true life story worth telling, but running in at three hours long there were times where I felt some scenes were unnecessary or just too bloody long, although not long enough in the case of Belfort's prison sentence. Either way, some will want more, I felt it was excess but there are some truly brilliant moments worth mentioning.

The scene where Jordan and Donnie take a strong type of quaalude called the Lemmon-714, the aftermath is hilarious as Jordan essentially freezes, drools and crawls his way to his car, driving home unscathed, or so he thinks, and it's called the "Cerebral Palsy" drug effect. My favourite scene though is the leaving speech, you actually feel a little bit bad for Belfort, but then you think to yourself why after all the bad things, then of course he flips and states clearly "I'M FUCKING STAYING". 

With over 500 f-bomb drops, drug and alcohol abuse like never before and pure style, The Wolf Of Wall Street has to be seen, and whilst I think it's not Oscar worthy aside from it's performances, the hype and reviews say it all, it's unmissable and intoxicatingly watchable.

The Wolf of Wall Street follows the lifestyle of brokers and investors in the 1980's and the corruption that occurred in this time. Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio) is a New York stock broker that is hoping to make some money by working in brokerage firm. Here he has a drink with his boss (Matthew McConaughey), who teaches Belfort about the life that he must lead to successfully live as a stock broker, a life of sex and drugs. Belfort, stunned by this at first, begins to accept this lifestyle. Black Monday speaks a bad day for the firm and leaves Belfort without a job. Belfort's wife Teresa finds him a job at a penny brokers.
At the penny brokers, Belfort reaches his true potential as he is able to secure investors and using the hack, pump and dump method makes a lot of money. Belfort then meets Donnie Azof, who becomes the first member of the newly established firm Stratton Oakmont that use the method just mentioned to make their money. Within this establishment, Belfort holds parties that usually involve prostitutes, drugs and alcohol. 
Belfort moves up the ranks as he invests in the IPO (initial public offering) of Steve Madden Ltd. He hides his money in Swiss bank accounts. 
Belfort continues his life as a high earning wolf by taking the Lemmon-714, a very powerful drug. Belfort and Donnie get high and Donnie almost dies. 
Jordan is arrested by the FBI while running an infomercial and is forced to cooperate with them as they he as they are offering him freedom. Jordan breaches his cooperation deal and the FBI shuts down Stratton Oakmont.  Jordan receives 36 months in a minimum security prison and eventually makes a living showing people how to work in sales.

Leonardo DiCaprio is terrific as the debaucherous man-boy, Jordan Belfort. Jonah Hill is equally wonderful as his sidekick, Donnie. There's quite a few laugh out loud moments in this movie, and many of them have to do with these two vibing off each other. The outrageous and lengthy lude scene at Jordan's house comes to mind here. All of the acting is top-notch. Even Margot Robbie, who plays Jordan's second wife, is turns in a great performance. By seeing her in the opening scenes, my mind immediately thought she was there to just be eye candy. A brainless, one-dimensional character that had no real bond or relationship with Jordan. I was very wrong, and she had so much more to offer than what I originally thought. 

WOWS is manic, crass, and engaging. It pulls us into this crazy world of people with entirely too much money on their hands. It is one heck of a ride to sit through this movie, honestly. The movie doesn't celebrate the kind of lifestyle Jordan and his buddies lead, but it definitely has a lot of fun in its portrayal of it. I may not have understood a whole lot of what was being explained sometimes but it was nonetheless interesting. Sometimes you're not even sure if you should laugh or just shake your head in astonishment that this is what goes on behind the closed doors of those Wall Street offices. 

Definitely worth seeing.

With Wall Street being as challenging as it is, "Wolf of Wall Street" serves as the one of the best movies gearing on Wall Street ever made.

That also serves for management skills. Everyone has the talent to influence their customers efficiently and professionally. There are necessities to show to people what to expect if they ever want to do anything with sales, management, or dealing anything that is in the business of money-making.

Once brokers start bringing in the big bucks, there are many risks that they start to take to become even more richer than they expect. Yes, the work place is not pretty in Wall Street. The foul language, the jealousy of other brokers, and the stress leads to negative effect. For Jordan Belfort though, he is the brokers motivational man to prove them that it is better to deal with problems by becoming rich than sitting around.

Martin Scorsese's "Wolf Of Wall Street" is very realistic on the true story of Jordan Belfort (played by Leonardo DiCaprio). Belfort started his business Stratton Oakmont in an abandoned auto-body shop. He hires a bunch of brokers with very little experience and an assistant named Donnie Azoff (played by Jonah Hill) another inexperienced broker, however Belfort turns Donnie into his top assistant for how motivated he is to become rich.

As soon as Belfort starts bringing in hard cash, he starts to make so much money that he does not know what to do with it. As soon as he runs out of options, his money spending consists of drugs, hookers, alcoholism, expensive boats, and above all vulgarity.

The opening of a movie is Belfort throwing midgets at money targets and almost crashing a chopper since he is flying his chopper while being high on drugs. The opening basically already gives viewers an idea of what were going to expect in this three hour film. DiCaprio does some brief descriptions of his life, how rich he is, and briefly about how so many authorities are after him (will not explain why otherwise that would be giving away too much of the movie).

What stood out for me in this movie is how someone like Belfort could take so many drugs and get through the day. How could he take cocaine, quaaludes, and morphine all at once. Does he have a schedule to plan them accordingly? Did he take some kind of chemistry course that gives him an idea of how the drugs work together? Or does he just evolve with the drugs over time? "Wolf Of Wall Street" has the answer to those questions. It also knows the effects of drugs and what quantity is over-dosing and dangerous.

This is one of my all time favorite movies. I have seen many films relating to Wall Street. Good and bad ones, however after experiencing this masterpiece by Scorsese, it makes viewers feel like they are just watching a movie relating to Wall Street for the first time.

This is the fifth film that Scorsese has worked with DiCaprio on. After working with DiCaprio for a variety of films including "The Aviator" "Shutter Island" "The Departed" and many more, Scorsese knows how someone like DiCaprio can deliver a knockout performance in a movie.

Also for DiCaprio I have realized that he also incorporates brilliant ideas to make this film successful. The chest beating scene with Matthew McConaughey (as Mark Hanna) and DiCaprio was an idea by DiCaprio. He realized that McConaughey's process before a movie to keep the attitude going was to do the chest beat. As soon as DiCaprio realizes this, he mentioned it to both Scorsese and McConaughey, they put in their film, and it just makes the film even more enthralling than it already is.

Overall, "Wolf Of Wall Street" is one not to be missed. It is surprisingly still in some theaters and on DVD and blue ray. I recommend if viewers have the opportunity to see it in the theaters still see it there because it is the big screen experience. Be ready for the thrill ride of raunchiness and vulgarity but make it one to remember. Four stars.
couldn't take my eyes off it. Scorsese, DeCaprio and Hill at their best.

The constant theme of Martin Scorsese's best work are the temptations of the flesh, never more aptly seen than though the prism of real-life subjects.  He's explored this through Jake LaMotta, Howard Hughes, Henry Hill and Jesus Christ, but in his new film The Wolf of Wall Street, Jordan Belfort may have the most savage appetite of them all.  Here, Scorsese turns his camera to the greed and avarice of the stock market boom of the late 80s that he sees in almost the same way as his great film Goodfellas, with a kid from the middle class who finds a short-route to riches and unapologetically enjoys the anything-goes lifestyle.  He wants anything and everything and gets it, no matter what.  Then, as Scorsese's subjects always do, must suffer for it.  Jordan races through life as fast as he can, acquiring anything and everything he can get his hands on.  Anything?  How about his own yacht with a helipad?  Of course, you'll need a helicopter to go along with it.

Like Goodfellas, which followed the personal real-life story of an outsider into the world of New York gangsters, The Wolf of Wall Street follows the rise and fall of Jordan Belfort, who narrates his own story with the energy of a runaway bullet train.  At 22, he is a nice kid from the middle class who gets a job with a legendary Wall Street firm L.J. Rothchild under the tutelage of Mark Hanna (Matthew McConaughey) a wiry drug-addict who not only trains the kid, but lets him in on the secrets of quick success.  "The name of the game," he tells Jordan," is moving the money from the client's pocket to your pocket."  This is a mantra that Jordan takes to heart, even if the client doesn't make a dime.

Then, only weeks after getting the job, Rothchild hits a brick wall on October 19th, 1987 - Black Monday - forcing the grand old lady to close its doors after 90 years.  Without a job, he starts from the bottom at the only firm that will hire him - a meager penny-stock firm that works out of an auto parts garage.  Jordan makes himself a superstar by proving how easy it is to scam the client to make money fast.  He takes over the business, building it from penny stocks to Blue Chips to IPOs born on the backs of screwing their clients.  To his surprise, he finds a small patch of money hungry brokers ready to follow his lead.  Most visible is a pudgy Jewish kid named Donnie (Jonah Hill) who becomes his right arm. Donnie is a glutinous yin to Jordan's yang, an otherwise nice Jewish kid who tries to throw off that moniker by dressing as WASP-like as he can.

In no time Jordan has turned the tiny boiler room brokerage firm into Stratton Oakmont, an operation built on crooked investments from which flows money, money, money leading to mountains of drugs, rooms full of naked women, and every expensive toy under the sun.  He feels guilty about nothing, taking Gordon Gekko's mantra of "Greed is Good" and making it into a religious sacrament.  Jordan is a modern-day Caligula, a Roman Emperor who makes no apologies for his gross avarice, his drug addiction, his sex addiction or any other morally reprehensible machination that allowed him to get it.  In no time at all he has be biggest house, the biggest boat, the best sports car, the fastest plane, and mounds and mounds of drugs.  He even trades in his supportive wife ("How I Met Your Mother"'s Cristin Milioti) for a gorgeous blonde trophy wife (Naomi Robbie).

In our minds, possibly not to Jordan, there is always the dread that the party will come to an end.  We feel that, but Jordan constantly skirts disaster, especially late in the film when he desperately needs to get to Switzerland and takes his own boat instead of a plane.  The plane explodes in mid-air and Jordan comes to believe that he may be invincible.  We feel that too, even when a boy scout FBI agent (Kyle Chandler) start snooping around Jordan's books.  The scene at sea, incidentally, is a not-so-thinly veiled call-back to DiCaprio's role in Titanic when his boat is caught in a violent storm and it looks like The King of the World won't make it out of this one either.

The rhythm of the film is familiar to anyone who has seen Scorsese's films before, what is amazing is that it's always infectious.  We know that what Jordan and Donnie are doing is morally reprehensible, but there is something in the attractiveness of their behavior that makes us privately hope that they won't get caught.  In our own way we like these guys, and that may come from our familiarity with their other films.  DiCaprio, in particular, turns in his very best performance, throwing away his good-guy image as a man who lives by appetite alone.  There are notes here that DiCaprio has never been able to display.  Yes, he's good looking, but he isn't afraid to look like a jerk.  Here he is able to display his talent for slapstick in a scene in which Jordan ingests a 15 year-old Quaalude that sends his body into a fit very close to cerebral palsy.  That's no good when he desperately needs to get to his car to stop Donnie from making a fatal mistake.  What is surprising is that this scene is played for laughs and it works!

This is a movie made up of two or three dozen perfect moments like that.  Overall it's energy is charged by the pacing and by DiCaprio's in-your-face narration.  This is a raunchy, messy, but ultimately exciting film about one guy who desires everything and gets it.  If it seems a bit too long, that's only because it is playing to the theme of wretched excess.  The end of the film sends Jordan on a toboggan slide that seems somewhat inevitable, causing his reign as king of the world to end with a whimper instead of a bang.  Does he learn a lesson from all his sins of lust and greed?  What do you think?
Very good UNTIL the last 30 minutes. Scorsese dragged this movie farther than it should have.

Far too long, and lacking a coherent theme or shape.  Compared to, say "Once Upon A Time In America", which covers a similar time span, this is far too reliant on DiCaprio to carry it along.  He does well, but ultimately I tired of him as the story crept to a rather obvious conclusion.  There are some good things along the way.  Joanna Lumley for one, in her first Scorsese movie adds a little sparkle.  Matthew McConaughey's cameo is memorable if a little flashy.  How much of it is true and how much fiction hardly matters.  Hopefully Scorsese has more great films in him, but this wasn't one.

Directed by Martin Scorsese, who follows up his family film Hugo (2011) with the most adult film imaginable. Based on Jordan Belfort's 2008 memoir, this is a cautionary black comedy about the absolute corruption of absolute power. It's also the wildest film Scorsese has made yet, and also his funniest, with some moments which will shock. You can't believe all this happened, but it looks brilliant. 1987, and Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio) becomes a stockbroker working for Mark Hanna (Matthew McConaughey), after Black Monday, Belfort is out of work, but he starts his own company, Stratton Oakmont, out of an abandoned garage, selling penny stocks for outrageously inflated prices. It makes him and business partner Donnie Azoff (Jonah Hill) millions in the space of a few years, and they lead an extravagant lifestyle, consisting of sex, booze and Quaaludes. But, it's not long before their activities catch the attention of FBI agent Patrick Denham (Kyle Chandler), who starts investigating, and Belfort and Azoff have to find a way to hide their millions. There's some scenes here you cannot believe Scorsese would have his cast doing, but it makes for fascinating and entertaining viewing, DiCaprio gives maybe his best performance, this shows that he should stop doing serious, brooding roles and do more comedy, he has a brilliant talent for it. But, it's wild and absolutely brilliant.

The Wolf of Wall Street - 8

Scorcese casts a satirical look at the adventures and misadventures of Jordan Belfort as soon as he becomes a stockbroker at Wall Street stock market. Debauchery and corruption, irreverently portrayed in this movie, were commonplace elements in the real life of this man while he conned his way into fortune. I haven't seen a Scorcese film in a long time, and yet "The Wolf of Wall Street" turned up to match exactly the only expectation I had - a movie that entertains and engages effortlessly by way of the trademark cinematic quality and vitality of Scorcese, but also seems to be a residuum of redundancy since, in many ways, this is a similar work to past outputs like "Goodfellas", for example. Was there any need to make a movie with such potentially contemptuous portray of debauchery? Maybe Scorcese thought so because otherwise it would be much more difficult to deviate the viewer's attention away from the fact that this is just more of the same. The same narrative concept, the same energy and aesthetics while we follow the rise and fall of the main characters (or group of main characters) connected to a criminal activity, the only differences are the thematic context and tone. The truth is, so much debauchery makes the movie a bit too long and slightly boring. What's so interesting about it?

But redundant or not, "The Wolf of Wall Street" is one more example of Scorcese's fine cinematic craft, technically perfect, very well polished, exciting and funny, with rock solid acting all around, I particularly liked DiCaprio and Jonah Hill. After watching this epic portrayal of Belfort's life of excess, one might have the natural tendency to look for an explanation or meaning behind all that, but I think that the main premiss of this work is to serve as an engaging and funny cinematic experience a bit like "American Hustle". I think these two movies have relatively similar premisses, but David O. Russel's effort, itself with an imprint of Scorcese DNA, is a sexier, more organic, funnier and more appealing cinematic experience to me. I guess it's a matter of taste that will dictate which movie one likes the most.

I know it's based on a true story, and it's supposed to just be an honest portrayal, but it seems to try to overdo and dramatize the wild lifestyle and illegal dealings of Belfort and his band of brokers.  I get from the portrayal that there is no good side to Belfort, and we really have no explanation of his actions except that he loves money and power (compare this to Christian Bale's character in "American Hustle." At times he is likeable.) Maybe we are to assume that that's just the way he is.  Anyway, I found it a waste of 2 hours.  Scorcese's still the best, but I don't think he tried when he made this one.

Scorsese delivers another instant classic, shifting his focus on the world of Wall Street, stocks, greed, and corruption. DiCaprio delivers his best performance so far as Jordan Belfort who succeeded in making millions from penny stocks which would lead to his eventual downfall.

Nothing like a good old fashioned retelling of financial fraud, hedonism, addiction and sheer debauchery on top of that comprising high calibre performances by both Leonardo DiCaprio and Jonah Hill, with a small dose of Matthew McConaughey whose minor role makes it all worthwhile. The film became infamous stateside due to controversy with the film being allegedly accountable for condoning/glamourising pugnacious behaviour and also for it's drug material. The overall tone of the film does not exactly promote the lifestyle of these characters who are so cartoonish they verge on being caricatures. 'The Wolf of Wall Street' is an intense film experience and it's always a delight to watch the film's leading ex-conman, Jordon Belfort (DiCaprio)'s depraved and repulsive antics, DiCaprio's screen presence is strong and his ability to carry the weight of the film on his shoulders shines through. Donnie Azoff (Jonah Hill) portrays Belfort's sidekick (if you will) gives justice to the supporting role. It's not long until Belfort's circle of greed expands among itself, with the FBI latching onto his master scheme with Belfort's contribution, it's long until the game is up which marks his demise of a lifestyle destined to result in jeopardy. Now, story wise, it's somewhat lacking, but if you can manage to get past that and relish some of the amazing set pieces and rowdy characters, the three hour run time will fly by. It's a film that's either loved or hated, rarely in-between. You'll either laugh, shake your head or frown upon the excessive unruly content, perhaps maybe all three at the same time! It's an unrelenting ride of hilarity and pure chaos from beginning to end. Scorsese on near top form, it's one you'll treasure for years to come.

Promotional interviews found Leonardo DiCaprio comparing his character in this film to Caligula and that simile isn't too far off. The Wolf of Wall Street follows an ambitious New York stockbroker who makes millions on shady deals and ultimately crashes because of his excesses. Because of this, the plot parallels many "rise and fall" Scorsese pictures such as Goodfellas, Raging Bull, and Casino. This movie distinguishes itself from its august peers thanks to its riotous tone, dark humor, and a fiery performance by DiCaprio.

Reaches the insane heights of Wall Street excess, but lacks little of the emotional fall - besides a few of the scenes detailing the derailing of Belfort's relationships with his family, there's really no moral at the end of this story to keep other opportunistic douchebag lying scumsucking asshats from admiring Belfort for daring to go so high in the first place. Instead of focusing on the enormity of Belfort's crimes, Scorcese really does come close to near-deifying the guy in an attempt to give DiCaprio another vehicle to shine in. 4/5 But outside of all that sanctimonious finger wagging, I fucking loved this fucking movie and I'd love to fucking watch it again. Fucking Scorcese, DiCaprio, and Hill pull this crazy madhouse of a story into an enjoyably excessive ride that doesn't have a weak moment for the entirety of it's 3 hr running time. Well done you beautiful fucking bastards. Well fucking done.

This is a movie that has created a lot of hype and I was very excited to see it; mostly because it's got Leonardo Dicaprio and I heard that he played a character unlike any he has before. Not only does Wolf of Wallstreet showcase the heights of Dicaprio's performance, but it delivers one of the best movies of 2013 with a brilliantly written script and oscar winning (sorry Leo) performances. There's just so much to talk about.
Let me start off with the story; its an autobiography of the rise and fall of a stockbroker, Jordan Belfort played by Dicaprio. The story is well paced, smart and has a near perfect balance of humour, drama and suspense. This of course is complimented by the very well written script which makes it witty but also allows a lot of the best moments of the story to be taken from the actors' performances but i'll get to that later. For its lengthy two hour and fifty five minute run, I was never bored. I was entertained from start to finish and that's not a feat a lot of movies can accomplish. The script and acting just fluidly meshed together, creating an experience I was just captivated by. In fact, I was a bit worried about the length but as I was watching I completely forgot about checking to see how long the movie had left as I was so engrossed in what was going on. There are themes of love, sex, betrayal, friendship and drugs; they all compliment the satisfying story and helped to keep the tension.
In terms of performances, let's just get this out of the way; DiCaprio is amazing. This is a character unlike anything I've ever seen him play and he does it so well, it's scary. His enthusiasm, his anger, and the ability to portray such an unstable drug addict is something to behold. He's funny and charming for five minutes then he just switches to aggressive and pig headed and then switches to kind, caring and loving, all the while he's narrating. He showcased so many different emotions in this film that it's hard to say that he's not capable of anything. In fact, I feel as if the oscars are beneath him as there should be a higher award given for his performance. Jonah's performance as his right hand man is also great and they have great chemistry on screen with a lot of the humour coming from them. Speaking of humour; Dicaprio debases himself a lot during this movie; there's this one scene where he's high and he's practically crawling to his car that had me rolling. His level of commitment is just ridiculous because there was no music or dialogue except him rolling and making strange movements to try to get the car door open and it was one of the funniest scenes I have ever seen. There are also a lot of nude scenes for him, but I suppose the ladies would enjoy that. Speaking of which, this movie really approaches the borderline of a porno. There was so much sex and nudity involved, it's ridiculous, which so helped to compliment the themes of power and money. I imagine that this would also shun away certain portions of the audience which is understandable as I don't think i've ever seen a movie that has been so raunchy and vulgar in a very long time. I mean, in the first five minutes, Dicaprio is sniffing cocaine out of a hooker's back-passage. Scintillating stuff. So much thought was put into translating the book to the screen that the director should also be praised for his accomplishment.
Most characters are memorable with their quirks and there was no weak acting; this is some top notch stuff. Even near the end, where there's a girl that was never mentioned in the entire story but was brought up as one of Belfort's first assistants forks out an emotional story which is heartbreaking. The movie just does this all very well; manages to keep all the characters interesting, no matter how little screen time they got. This, of course, was also the movie's flaw; they tried to introduce too much characters; so much that they could not keep up with each one and their various resolutions were unsatisfying. This is a minor gripe though, as the ambition of the movie can be appreciated. However, its the metamorphosis of Belfort that manages to carry the story from start to finish and it's so filling that you won't know or even realize that you missed anything else.
With the performance of a lifetime given by Dicaprio, a brilliant script and well paced movie with great performances from start to finish, there's no reason NOT to watch Wolf of Wallstreet. Sell me this pen. 9.5/10

The fifth collaboration between Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio, The Wolf of Wall Street tells the true story of the rise and fall of Jordan Belfort (DiCaprio), a New York stockbroker who made it big in the wake of the financial crisis of the late '80s by shady and frequently illegal means. More interesting is what he does with his new found fortune: what follows is a heady tale of excess and debauchery based on Belfort's own memoirs.

Despite the more recent financial turmoil, or perhaps because of it, the image of the '80s stockbroker has resurfaced for a new generation. Belfort's story strays into the early '90s, but the general aesthetic of the era has the same nostalgic feel, and the messages seem to be the same. Even if we openly loathe bankers, there's a voyeuristic fascination in watching their decadent lifestyle - or what we imagine such a lifestyle to be like: high stress, fast living, dubious morality and plenty of drugs and sex to boot. The Wolf of Wall Street gives its audience a welcome window into this world.

The story begins when Jordan arrives in the city as a bright eyed, newly qualified broker; having already achieved his youthful dream of working on Wall Street. After an initially unwelcome brief induction into a life of cocaine and lunchtime cocktails by his new boss Mark Hanna (Matthew McConaughey) the rug is pulled out from under his feet, and he soon swaps blue chips for penny stocks, trading shares worth a fraction of a dollar from a Long Island brokerage on a strip mall.

Upon realising that these unlisted stocks can fetch a much higher commission than blue chips, he decides to go into business with a bunch of unscrupulous buddies who know a thing or two about sales, using their silver tongues to make millions by trading them on a massive scale, all the while trying to stay one step ahead of the law. For in truth he is committing outright stock fraud - the details of which are fairly complicated; even Belfort himself chooses not to bore us with the details with his tongue in cheek narration.

The stellar cast is rounded out by players including Jonah Hill, as Belfort's toothy associate Donnie, Rob Reiner as his complicit accountant father Max Belfort, and Jon Favreau as lawyer Manny Riskin.

The movie treads a thin line between satire and glorification, but Jordan is undoubtedly the hero of the piece, and the FBI agents on his trail the antagonists he must outwit. As an audience, we are invited to his party, and we witness nothing of the effects that Belfort's deceptions have had on those who were duped into buying his shares - bearing in mind these 'customers' are average people parting with their savings, not huge companies dealing in huge sums of money. This disconnection effectively puts us in Belfort's shoes: much as they must have appeared to him, they are mere voices on the end of a phone.

But Jordan is not portrayed as completely heartless. No matter how large his company grows, swelled with a never-ending number of skilled and promising applicants, his loyal gang of hometown reprobates are never left behind, and maintain high-ranking positions until the end. Even when arrested, and forced to wear a wire by the FBI, he attempts to warn Donnie, rather than let him incriminate himself.

Gratuitous drug use and sexual content aside, the film's vulgarity can perhaps be summed up by its smashing of the record for the most uses of the f-word in a mainstream non-documentary film, at the rate of around three a minute. The only film scoring higher is a documentary devoted to the word.

Much of the decadence is played for laughs, or at least as a showcase of extravagance, but coupled with the basic shock value of the actions themselves. One memorable sequence sees Belfort snorting cocaine to counteract the effects of a powerful sedative, paralleled with the Popeye cartoon playing on the television in the background.

The film does little to condemn Belfort - although his lifestyle unravels, and he is ultimately incarcerated, any true comeuppance is minimal. This is a reflection of the truth: Belfort's sentence was just four years, of which he served less than two, which, if the film is to be believed, were in a comfortable minimum security environment for white collar offenders.

These days, he still makes a handsome living as a motivational speaker lecturing on sales technique, and of course, anyone who gets their autobiography made into a Scorsese picture starring Leonardo DiCaprio must have lucked out in the long run.

Critics of an older audience will shy away from this movie labeling it as a grotesque, vulgar, and an over the top depiction glorifying sex and drugs. However most of those people who critique this film on those grounds are the same people who usually like to pretend that things like that don't actually exist, especially among the rich and successful. Unfortunately for them that's not exactly the case. Yes there are people who are rich from immoral things, yes there are millionaires who are addicted to drugs, yes there are people who are richer than you and are complete scum. Many people refuse to believe that somebody who's worked half as hard as them and is ten times richer than them at half the age exists. With that being said, I believe this movie has been reviewed under the most biased light. I myself went into the theater expecting a total "party boy" sell out film targeting the younger "Project X" generation. Instead I got another great Scorsese tale of hubris that I would put in a three disc box set with Goodfellas and Casino.

Martin Scorsese is known for his lavish, over-the-top film extravaganzas just as much as he is for his gritty, "real" projects. 'The Wolf of Wall Street' is definitely in the former camp. The big budget, bloated look at the life of Wall Street conman Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio) tests the boundaries with its content, as the three-hour piece is chock-full of sex, drugs, language and general debauchery - a true portrait of life on Wall Street in the 1990s. While the runtime is extreme, 'Wolf' doesn't feel as long as it is, considering all of the action packed in. 'Wolf' is the definition of a dark comedy - as the greed, sadness and roller coaster ride of Belfort's life includes plenty of parts that are cruelly ironic but funny to a point. Among the rest of the cast, Jonah Hill as Belfort's cohort Donnie Azoff, Margot Robbie as his second wife Naomi Lapaglia and Kyle Chandler as FBI agent Patrick Denham do respectable jobs, and a minor role by Matthew McConaughey is appreciated. Things that stand out about 'Wolf' include its editing - perhaps a strange aspect to highlight, but it's noticeable in this instance - and its soundtrack, which is very fitting. While there was plenty of controversy upon the release of the film for glorifying the life of Belfort, it's fair to say there's not a whole lot of glamor here, even if it appears so on the surface. 'The Wolf of Wall Street' is loud, obnoxious, witty and wild - it's not Scorsese's best work, nor is it his worst. It's a film worth watching just once in your life, to say you've seen it, but not much beyond that.

The Wolf of Wall Street is easily Martin Scorsese's best and most daring directorial effort in a long time.  I don't think we've ever seen greed, excess and all-around insanity portrayed on film quite like this before.  This flick holds absolutely nothing back.  Collaborating with Leonardo DiCaprio for a fifth time, Scorsese really brings out the best in one of this generation's more versatile actors.  Who the hell knew DiCaprio could be this funny?  Just as impressive is Jonah Hill, who gets to play an actual character here instead of yet another variation on his 'Superbad' role.  Scorsese throws more sex, drugs and profanity at the screen here than in all his other films combined.  Some will be in on the joke...others won't and will probably hate this movie.  For me, the only thing that kept this from being one of Scorsese's best was the length.  At three hours long they could've easily cut 20-30 minutes to keep the pace tighter and the film wouldn't have lost any of its punch.  Definitely not for everyone, but worth seeing for the brilliant performances.  And just keep telling yourself...this is a true story.

While there is so much to admire in this adaptation of the memoir on Wall Street's excesses by Jordan Belfort, it is one of the great Scorsese's weaker recent efforts just for the fact that it is overlong (3 hours) and massively overdone. 

Now-regular Scorsese collaborator Leonardo DiCaprio plays Belfort who we follow from his small Wall Street start in 1987 where his interaction with his boss at L.F. Rothschild (Matthew McConaughey in a stellar brief key role that sets the tone for the whole movie), who lives high with a lot of casual sex and drugs until going to prison when firm goes bankrupt, shapes Belfort's future. After losing his job, he sells penny stocks at a small Long Island business and excels, leading him to start his own business with his salesman neighbor Donnie Azoff (Jonah Hill) that he names "Stratton Oakmont". The firm soon becomes the talk of the town and known for its employees' decadent lifestyle of sex and drugs. And we get a lot of it here. I have no problem with scenes of sexuality or nudity but here there is one too many to basically convey the same message so at some point it feels utterly redundant.  Cast includes Margot Robbie (in a breakout role) as Belfort's trophy second wife, Kyle Chandler as the FBI agent investigating Belfort and Jean Dujardin as a corrupt Swiss banker who helps Belfort get money out of the US. 

I must say I thoroughly enjoyed the first half of this dark comedy that had a proper mix of raunchiness and entertainment with an over-the-top (in a good way) performance by DiCaprio. But it just feels a bit repetitive after some time and loses some of its initial interest when the FBI gets into the picture. This could have easily been a two-hour movie (it is surprising that the initial running time was nearly 30-45 minutes longer!). As an example, there is one scene where DiCaprio and Hill get a huge dose of some old strong drug with DiCaprio having to drive stoned to a country club to call a private investigator and then returns home to find Hill run amok under the influence. While the acting is great, it is just far too long.  

There is a lot to admire about the movie and it is well worth watching if only for DiCaprio and some outrageous scenes (some of which are mouth-opening) but I am just disappointed as it could have been so much better given the talent involved. Adapted to the screen by Terence Winter (TV's "The Sopranos" and "Boardwalk Empire"). Nominated for 5 Oscars: Picture, Director, Actor (DiCaprio), Supporting Actor (Hill), Adapted Screenplay.

As much as I loathe Kanye West, I couldn't help but be pulled into the preview for this film, pulsating to the beat of his ever-so-tacky "Black Skinhead".  Add to it that Martin Scorsese (Hugo) directed this gig, and I almost wanted to see it in theaters.  I opted not to, because Oscar movies generally disappoint me.  However, when I finally saw it on Blu-ray, not only was I disappointed, I was borderline disgusted.  It's no secret that 
Leonardo DiCaprio (The Great Gatsby) is Scorsese's go-to boy for just about anything.  However, despite DiCaprio not really being able to pull off something non-crazy (exceptions: 'Inception' and 'The Departed'), Scorsese usually pieces together a decent film.  With this one, they both went for broke and the results were atrocious.  So many things to pick apart that I'm not even going to begin to.  The cast is stacked with talent - Matthew McConaughey (Mud), Kyle Chandler (Broken City), Rob Reiner (Dickie Roberts: Former Child Star), Jon Favreau (Iron Man 3), and  Jean Dujardin (The Artist) - but instead of lingering on those brief shining moments, it spends more time following DiCaprio and Jonah Hill's (This is the End) characters' drug-fueled sexual exploits than creating a film that you could even begin to care about.  Margot Robbie (About Time) leads a host of tramps that are on screen for no other reason than to shed their clothes.  There is not one redeeming quality about this film, and by the end, you're hoping someone dies in an epic way so as to almost justify three hours of your time being wasted.  Spoiler alert: no such payoff exists.  In fact, there is no real payoff at all.  It's a complete waste.  Sure, Leo goes bonkers and got another Oscar nomination, but to what end?  He'll never achieve greatness by basically playing varying degrees of the same character over and over again.  Hill also landed another nomination, but he's equally as Kirk Lazarus (if you get that joke, I give you props) in his role.  Honestly, what I'm most disappointed in - other than wasting three hours of my life on this mess - is Scorsese.  What a waste of talent on this piece of garbage.  Should have known it was going to be tacky and awful just by having Kanye as part of their marketing effort.

As big of a fan of Scorsese I am, I will be the first to say I didn't enjoy this film. In fact I would have to say it is the weakest film he has done (in my opinion). I saw this film as a combination of  "American Hustle", "Goodfellas", and "Casino". It's like "American Hustle" because it takes two reputable actors (Hill and DiCaprio) and makes them very unlikable. It takes the run time from "Casino". And, the ending is basically copy-paste from "Goodfellas". There are some generally funny moments, but in the end, it boils down to a lot of sex, the F word, and drugs for 3 hours. And yes I get it, they're all criminals, but this is almost taking it too far. It's as if the film is just throwing F bombs, and boobs at the screen to see what gets a laugh out of you, and that is just juvenile from a director of this stature. I am glad I saw the film and gave it a try, but, that being said I found it very drawn out and would not consider watching it again. I love you Scorsese, I really really do, and I understand that every director is entitled to one "dud film". "The Wolf of Wall Street" is that dud for me.

A cautionary tale with moral ambiguity, "The Wolf Of Wall Street" is so fast, loud and energetic that it just might make for a suitable substitute for cocaine for withdrawing addicts or movie junkies.

Martin Scorsese's latest black comedy,  "The Wolf of Wall Street" is a three-hour thrill ride that's packed with outrageous, raw, jaw-dropping scenes. This fantastic biopic captures the best and the worst times of a young, eager entrepreneur, turned money-hungry swindler, Jordan Belfort, whom Leonardo DeCaprio portrays flawlessly. Scorsese's fifth collaboration with DiCaprio, makes it his best and funniest film in more than a decade.
This party-themed knockout film revolves around greed, sex, money and drugs - all fascinating to watch. The events unfold with a hilarious, fast-paced, rhythm that will leave the audience speechless. "The Wolf of Wall Street" is incredibly bold, wildly entertaining and full of riveting moments. It's all-star cast gives off an intense energy and have a great chemistry with each other. Even though DiCaprio plays a character who has such a self-indulging, vulgar and off-putting demeanor, it is hard to hate him. In fact, the audience will fall in love with the Wolf. 
Simply put, this comedy is an instant classic that's pure and sheer genius. Martin Scorsese is a brilliant director who created a funny, smart and stylish film. This is the best picture of 2013, hands down.

There is a lot of energy, a lot of it. This energy comes from characters you wouldn't expect to play these roles. I was very surprised to see these characters in these roles and I enjoyed this film very much.

The Wolf of Wall Street is a hilarious, absurd look at greed and how it operates in our culture, which is why the film has been so divisive. Many people seem to be shying away from the film because of the controversy surrounding it, including the accusation that it glorifies amoral behavior. What those people fail to realize is, that's the point; the film is portraying that lifestyle and we are supposed to be shocked by it.
And Shocked I was by the film, which was unbelievably raunchy and coarse. I was totally swept up by the film, laughing my head off constantly. The performances, especially DiCaprio and Hill's are phenomenal and add to the energy of the film. 
Another reason  people will shy away from Wolf is because of it's length, but the film moves remarkably fast and keeps you engaged the whole time. This is due in large part to Scorsese's direction, which is flawless and exhilarating; he's able to create a frenzied pace that is undeniable.  So ignore the controversy and forget worrying about the length; The Wolf of Wall Street is a must see and one of the best films in recent memory.

This is Scorcese at his electrifyingly best.  This was the best film of 2013, and Leonardo DiCaprio once again delivers an astonishing performance that should have been rewarded with Oscar Gold.  He lost, of course, to McConnaughey, whose fifteen minute role in this film equals and surpasses anything else he has ever done.  But the real star here is Scorcese.  He manages to take these absolutely repulsive human beings, getting obscenely rich off of our money (illegally obtained) and presents them in a way that makes them not only endearing, but almost inspirational.  They only know how to live all out.  Moderation does not exist in their vocabulary, and Scorcese sees the poetry and the danger in it.  He sees that they are both repugnant and overwhelmingly attractive.  He presents them to the audience without making judgements against them, while simultaneously making their lives of extreme excess thrill in the vain of Super Bowl celebration.  Grand, daring filmmaking at its best.  I dare you to look away.

In this raunchy, sex scandal filled film that falls somewhere between action, comedy, and drama, Leonardo DiCaprio plays the licentious stockbroker Jordan Belfort. Belfort takes the stock market by storm selling penny stocks, making more money than he knows what to do with. He eventually gets caught up in a conflict between his family and his new wild lifestyle. His adventures with drugs, alcohol, adultery, prostitution, and stock market fraud are what essentially gives this movie its zest. I thoroughly enjoyed following the misadventures of Jordan Belfort every step of the way. Despite all the evidence against him, Leo's portrayal of a character that should be loathed, is adored by viewers. It is an unforgettable, action packed film with endless comedy. Martin Scorsese directed a comedic masterpiece and DiCaprio carried out the role in a way I would describe as nothing shy of perfection. I would highly recommend this movie to anybody who is willing to devote roughly three hours and laugh/gasp the whole way through.

This might be, arguably, Leonardo DiCaprio's best performance yet.  Yes, I know what you're thinking: "In a career full of incredible performances, how do you single out just one as someone's best?"  That's a great question, and one that I really can't answer.  But Leonardo DiCaprio, as he is wont to do, hits a grand slam with his performance here.  The main difference is that, as opposed to his other performances, he seems to be having a blast here.  It seems like he really got to let loose and probably have more fun on set than he probably has been allowed to before.  I'm not saying that he doesn't have fun acting, but in this film it was even more apparent.  And it certainly benefits the character he's playing and the story the film is telling.  This a story about all the excesses, all the depravity, debauchery, the drugs, the sex, etc, etc, etc.  It's all here, just when you think the film can't get any crazier with its depravity, they up the ante.  The film, it could be argued, glorifies Jordan's actions and that's certainly a valid point.  My response to that, however, is that to show Jordan at the lowest of lows you have to show him getting to the highest of highs.  Not unlike another Scorsese film, GoodFellas.  So in that regards, I think the film is successful.  Because, in both movies, no matter how great things were for Jordan at his highest, there's only one place to go at your highest...and that's down.  And that's exactly what happened.  It would be glorifying his actions if, at the end of the day, he did all this illegal shit and didn't pay for it in the eyes of the law.  That's when people can go and say "well if he did it, then I can."  The fact of the matter is that while, yes, he made millions and millions of dollars doing highly illegal shit, eventually he had to pay for it all.  I think that's really the point of the film.  All the excesses, all the partying, all that debauchery eventually caught up to Jordan, and by extension his company, and bit him in the ass.  With that said, the film is actually surprisingly funny, and it even has one of the funniest scenes of any film last year.  It's certainly got a very irreverent sense of humor.  So, if you're someone that gets easily upset over stupid shit, then this film's gonna drive you nuts.  But, that irreverent humor definitely was very entertaining and made what is an interminably long film, even though it doesn't feel like it, really easy and entertaining to watch.  What I thought about Jordan Belfort as a character is that he was a man who was willing to do anything, white-collar crime related, to get to where he wanted to be and that was to be a millionaire.  And the way he did so wasn't even through his own intelligence.  He didn't do this because he was the smartest, he did this because he was the shrewdest and he knew how to con/manipulate people into buying penny stocks for companies that aren't gonna go far.  He knew how to use his clients to get exactly what he needed, and he knew how to manipulate the system in his favor.  Another thing that's very noticeable about Jordan is that he had this weird charisma and way of motivating his employees to do just about absolutely anything for him.  He was definitely a great motivational speaker, if this film is any indication.  He could motivate any of his employees to give his mother cyanide and convince them that it's actually good for her.  Granted, things never got THAT far, though I'm sure that the real Jordan Belfort certainly embellished a lot.of his escapades.  But there's something about Jordan and his motley crew that sort of made me think that they were the Manson Family of Wall Street.  Of course, they wouldn't go to the extremes the Mansons did, but Jordan's employee would do absolutely anything and everything for him, so there's some weird cult leader thing going on with Jordan.  It's certainly not overt, but you can notice it.  The movie, as usual, is exquisitely shot as Scorsese is at the top of his game as a director.  I think the film could've used some trimming here and there, but all in all, the film is an easy 179 minutes to watch.  The humorous tone certainly helped a lot, and Leonardo DiCaprio and cast were clearly having a blast.  So this is a pretty damn great film if you ask me.  If you're, somehow, offended at the behavior the film portrays...then good, because that's the intention.  Great film and a testament to Scorsese's strength  and diversity as a filmmaker that he can go and do all these different projects when he could very easily do GoodFellas, or The Departed, over and over and over again.

I had a chance to read lots of positive reviews regarding this black comedy directed by Martin Scorsese, based on Jordan Belfort's memoir of the same name. Probably that's why my expectations were set up very high. I cannot say that I didn't like it, but I found out that during the very long (almost 3) hours I wasn't too excited by the screenplay written by Terence Winter. The stars were on much higher level, especially Leonardo DiCaprio as Jordan Belfort, a New York stockbroker who runs a firm that engages in securities fraud and corruption on Wall Street in the 1990s.

The film has a real stardom with Jonah Hill, Margot Robbie, Matthew McConaughey, Kyle Chandler, Rob Reiner, Jon Bernthal, Jon Favreau, and Jean Dujardin. It is the fifth collaboration between Scorsese and DiCaprio and it is obvious that they like each other's style of work.  

This film was mainly criticized for its moral ambiguity, sexual content, presence of drugs, vulgarity, and use of animals - but still managed to gross over $387 million worldwide against a $100 million budget, and was nominated for five Academy Awards, including Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Actor and Best Supporting Actor for DiCaprio and Hill respectively, but failed to win in any category. It was the first major film to be distributed entirely digitally. The film also holds the record for the most uses of the word "fuck" in a mainstream non-documentary film (it was almost impossible to beat the South Park movie, but these guys did it with  doubling the time when you can use those words) . In January 2014 Jonah Hill revealed in an interview with Howard Stern that he only made $60,000 the film while his co-star, Leonardo DiCaprio who also produced, received $10 million. Hill was determined to work with Scorsese, and wanted to play Donnie Azoff so badly that he was willing to do what it took to get the part.

I had a problem with being interested in characters who are interesting only when they were high - and that interest was in their heads only, because I do not think that the victims of these guys were so enthusiastic in financial dealings as they were. Not a bad movie, acting and directing were very good, but it had its own flows, especially regarding the screenplay and to be believable!

Overall this film was well-acted and -directed, mixing frenetic drama with almost adolescent dark humor in a way that worked.

With it's unflinching look into the debauched, drug addled, sex crazed, completely hedonistic lifestyle of main character, Jordan Belfort, The Wolf of Wall Street is by far the most scandalous and controversial movie of 2013. It makes Eyes Wide Shut look like Barney the dinosaur. It has multiple NC-17 style sex scenes and more f-words than any movie to date. The main character is obsessed with his own hubris and the desire for more and more wealth. He screws people out of their money on Wall Street and shows no real love for anyone, only using them to fulfill his hedonistic lifestyle. The movie is a black comedy, and is quite hilarious at times, especially in a scene of a quaalude binge gone bad. I also felt the movie to be quite relevant. Given our sinful nature as humans, we are all prone to selfishness and the pursuit of our own happiness and ideals, even at the expense of others. Our consumer culture feeds the idea that we need to have more stuff, that our happiness is more important than anything, and that making a ton of money will fulfill that desire to be happy. Make more, spend more, get, get, get. The Wolf of Wall Street illustrates what happens when someone completely gives into that greedy, hedonistic lifestyle, living only to make more, have more, and feel pleasure at all times and at all costs. The result: self destruction. I thought The Wolf of Wall Street was an excellent movie. It made me laugh, it made me cringe, but it also made me take a good look at my life, values, and relationships. The hubris and downfall of Jordan Belfort reminds me of what's really important in life; not getting rich or taking from others, but loving and giving to those whom I love.

The case of Jordan Belfort is undoubtedly particular, but belongs to the echoes of the maelstrom of Wall Street in the '80s, where President Reagan supported these frivolous trends (Have you seen the photo of the president with Frank Sinatra, or Michael Jackson?) while claiming a heavy materialism and conservative values. The next film makes it look Belfort as an illegal version of Donald Trump, and a politically correct film than "American Psycho". In this universe, a moderately agile person could handle, sell junk and make millions, which is what happens in "The Wolf Of Wall Street"

The film promises to narrate the rise and fall of this tycoon. Frankly, perhaps the best definition gave Matt Seitz (in his page "Roger Ebert"): "Imagine the last thirty minutes of Goodfellas stretched out to three hours" That is the virtue and the defect . Here Scorsese portrays Belfort with the charisma as which the director did their other productions, and providing a small group of gang. In the movie, Leonardo Di Caprio achieved (based on skillful leadership ) triumph over their poor and mediocre fellows, and then drag them to the same ball, getting an army of loyal followers that operate in the same way that he and live like him.

Things work when approaching steps humor: all are eminently likeable, without annoying pretensions or ego swelling. There are excesses, but are not very visual, and in the background the protagonists are just a couple of dumbs but now with money and drugs and certain level of sophistication , so the comedy gears work great: just look at DiCaprio down stairs like babies (as he says) because the drugs do not allow him to walk, or in an exchange of thoughts with the owner of Swiss bank or one of the aunts of his girlfriend. Add up the directorial style with Off vooice, talking to the camera in an accomplice tone, collations of time, information, monologues, moderately competent soundtrack, etc. that add a touch on the mood or the general line

While the film does not exactly qualify comedy but contains enough and kill you with laughter, on the other hand "The Wolf Of Wall Street" does not offer much more than that

Watching The Wolf of Wall Street is like staring at the heavy, hairy scrotum and throbbingly tumescent penis of American capitalism ready to explode its essence no matter what the consequences.  Its equivocation of the capitalist American dream with a testosterone-fueled orgy of masculinity proves quite brilliant.  A hilarious, yet dark film, The Wolf of Wall Street does not feature a single respectable character--they are all scum, ready and willing to sell themselves and those around them to the highest bidder.  

Wolf of Wall Street is about seeing life as a cost-benefit analysis without any regard to ethics or repercussions.  It follows the typical Scorsese arc of rise and fall along with the inevitable voice-over, but the subject-matter and the tone of the film are different enough to make this not feel derivative of his earlier works.  Here, Scorsese is working at the edge of drama and often spilling over into satire, and it is a damn funny film.  But one that also makes one slightly uneasy about the consequences of our laughter.

The Wolf of Wall Street was a bit of a disappointment to me. The movie was way too long, there was little character development, and I was bored in a couple of scenes. Performance wise this movie is great. Leonardo DiCaprio, Jonah Hill and everyone in the cast is great. I believed everyone's performance. But with those performances there isn't really any character development. We get practically no character development with Gordon's wife, and before you ask which one I'm talking about both of them. The second wife had potential to have a lot of character development, but we get none. In the end scene we are suppose to feel bad for her but I don't. Now the problem most people have is the length. I thought I was not going to have a problem with the length but I did. A lot of this movie could have been cut off. All of the sex scenes were unnecessary. Bringing me to my other problem, too much sex and nudity. I'm not the one to complain when there is sex or nudity in a movie. But this over did it. To the point where I felt uncomfortable watching it. I wasn't bored in a lot of parts watching this. I was bored in other parts when the movie slows down. I was invested in the story, but that would break off when they show nudity and sex. The sex scenes could be cut off completely; there is no use for them at all. I did laugh in a lot of parts that made up for the boring parts. But the biggest flaw of the movie is the length. And I'm going to keep on complaining. It does not have to be three hours long. I really did want to love this movie. I wanted it to be in my top three movies of the year. But I didn't love it, I liked it. The movie was fine; I would recommend it to a lot of people. But I wanted to like this more than American Hustle, but I ended up liking American Hustle more. Would I still put this in my best movies of 2013? Probably, but I don't think it would be as high as I wanted it to. Maybe I need to see it again. I'll probably buy it on Blu-Ray. What a letdown.

I almost passed on this film because it had Matthew McConaughey in the trailer.  I can only take so much *smug" in a two hour period.  But, since its a Scorsese film I gave in--I am a true fan and adore all of his work for one reason or another.  So, like many previous Scorsese films, we have a tale of the life arch of another psychopath.  The parallels between Henry Hill in GoodFellas and Belfort in Wolf are uncanny.  But while GoodFellas has something human about it all...this movie doesn't.  A glimpse into the sick word of these type of people is entertaining in a voyeuristic way but I left the film feeling a bit irritated.  Thinking on how DiCaprio and Scorese portray their efforts to make this film as some sort of crusade, I found myself thinking, "did we really need another movie glorifying the escapades of another flaming narcissist/psychopath? " Compared to GoodFellas, this story lacks any human quality.  There is no one in the film with qualities that are worthy of rooting for...or makes them the least bit likable.  Any your left wondering why such people deserve 2 hours of film dedicated to showcasing their hedonistic and predatory antics.

The Wolf of Wall Street is a brutally crass and mercilessly blunt movie about the exploitation of niche opportunities in the wall street market. Brilliantly crafted together by none other than Scorsese, with his main man Di Caprio to carry the movie on his shoulders, this movie (not for the faint hearted) is fun, hilarious, dramatic, and most importantly, entertaining. Jonah Hill is really coming forwards as a talented actor, along with everyone else in the film, especially the gorgeous, and brave Margot. It is a thrill ride following the life of a drug-riddled, workaholic, money-driven sex-fiend, and it is such a relief to watch, as it doesn't take itself too seriously and takes you out on a captivating date. Without a doubt, Scorsese has once again made a fine gem.

Wolf does not disappoint.  All the elements of Scorsese are here;  We have a New York backdrop, we have a protagonist with moral ambiguity at best, and we have the invisible wall broken between audience and characters, as Belfort talks to us directly throughout the film.  Further, we get an inside look, a glimpse, into an underworld unfamiliar to most.  We say "I can't believe I just saw that", and we are fascinated with the sex, the drugs, the violence, and the crime, as we sit, safely in our voyeuristic theater seats, enjoying the spectacle.  These are all classic Scorsese elements, and I loved every bit of them.  Wolf parallels Casino, in many ways for me, in terms of how Scorsese tells his story, and how we respond.  In addition, We have an amazing cast of actors, DiCaprio and McConaughey of many, but of course, the big surprise here was the performance of Jonah Hill, who continues to amaze us as as his craft develops and hones.  I'm not sure if the high point was the prosthetic penis, or the incredulous Ludes overdose at the country club.  Indeed, Wolf was highly entertaining, I was pleased they did not edit the film down to a vanilla size, running close to 3 hours, and I will watch it again and savor all of its gritty insane Wall Street moments. My only small critique would be this:   I was left wondering if just a little bit of meat could have been added on to the bones of the "pump and dump", which is primarily the fraud that was committed here:  In other words, the operators, owned shares of their chop stocks, then sold over inflated shares to investors, then dumped their own shares, and thus, riches were made.  I'll have to watch Wolf a second time around to see if this was fully explained to us, or if it was glossed over.  It might be an 'in the weeds' detail that many folks would care less to know, but an important one in my view.  That said, there was plenty of bad to go around here, and I don't think the idea that Belfort was essentially a bad guy, but a guy that we care about, was lost to us.  Final critique, I wished we had a little more of an epilogue beyond the pen sales seminar in New Zealand.  Not so much with regard to Belfort.  The end of his tale, is morally ambiguous, and that is appropriate.  Did he change?  Did he learn from his mistakes?  Maybe not.  But, I'm left wondering about his wife, whom he punched in the gut, his daughter, who he almost kidnapped, his friends and colleagues who he ultimately betrayed to save his own neck.  What became of them?  Another 15 minutes would have been great, but that aside, another great film from the legendary Scorsese.

Martin Scorsese's wildly entertaining, "technically-a-biopic" on Wall Street extraordinaire Jordan Belfort is 3 hours (technically 2 hours 59 minutes and 52 seconds) tells the coke fueled story of a man making nearly a million dollars a week by the time he's 26. Portrayed by Leonardo DiCaprio (Scorsese's new Deniro) Leo brings fun and exciting life to the role of this drugged up money master. In a supporting role, Jonah Hill brings one of the most hilarious roles of the year. A must see for anyone looking for a good time.

Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio have history together. At times they have walked a thin line but the end result has always been interesting. This time it is also electrifying.
At three hours this movie is spellbinding throughout. Director and lead play their parts perfectly and a strong supporting cast, spearheaded by Jonah Hill, and assisted by the currently hot Matthew McConaughey (his is a small part which he could have played during a lunch break), compliment the piece. 
DiCaprio is slyly flamboyant as Jordan Belfort the rip-off merchant that for all his faults you cannot fail to like. The script is sharp, funny at times and presumably true to life.   
If the mark of a good film is that scenes from it stick with you, this succeeds many times over. It could not have been easy to make, but it is a compelling watch and readily appreciated.

From the second you initially hear Leo's voice, to the second you see "directed by Martin Scorsese" appear during the credits, the "Wolf" howls loudly at the audience and never takes a break to settle in, the film jumps around and impresses with its acting, editing, story, and pure chaotic elements.

Well, what can I say about the Wolf of Wall Street? - gripping, hilariously entertaining and rather shocking.

Based on the shockingly accurate story of the New York's financial elite, DiCaprio stars as the hideously, psychotically annoying Jordan Belfort from his rise to one of the most renowned (and obviously richest) stockbrokers on Wall Street who lives the life of luxury and endless riches to hitting rock bottom with crime and corruption and the target of government investigation.

You'd be blind to think this part was not made for Mr DiCaprio - the star executes this greedy, annoying, conceited character whilst still retaining his character's likability to cash-strapped audiences with is life of luxury and excitement. DiCaprio really gives his all in this performance, despite probably deserving the Oscar after his fourth acting nomination this year compared to McConaughey's first ever nomination and win, Dallas Buyers Club was just heart-breaking and only rarely does the Academy go all out on honoring a comedy.

A thoroughly deserved with for Best Actor in a Comedy/Musical at the Golden Globes - this movie is hilarious, and with all due respect to the cast of American Hustle, this picture should have definitely won Best - Comedy/Musical. You can help but laugh at the side-splitting exchanges between Belfort with the corrupt Swiss Banker, Jean-Jacques Saurel (Jean Dujardin) when we see Jordan's life of luxury begin to descend from this point on. "What I'm asking, you Swiss dick, is are you going to f*ck me over?"... "I understand perfectly, you American sh*t." The comedic timing at this point, honestly, was impeccable. I was cracking up.

Even though it's long, you kinda lose track of the time. You're caught up in a wild that just doesn't seem possible how such a way of earning a wealthy lifestyle can be unnoticed by the feds for such a prolonged amount of time - and with so many loopholes.

Although minimal, I was rather impressed with the brief performance of DiCaprio's on screen first wife Teresa (played by Cristin Milioti) truly capturing the tempestuous wrongdoings of her husband's greed and infidelity. But, the supporting (if not central performance) which truly exemplifies a man's love of greed and losing it all through descending into anarchy was Jonah Hill's performance. Now, I'm the first to admit, I'd never really seen Jonah Hill in a major, critically-acclaimed and I will have to check out Moneyball to confirm this, but, oh my god, Hill's comedic talents truly play up this name in this movie... so convincing as a young newlywed wanting a piece of the big time despite not even being 30 years old!

One of the greatest directors of our times, greated with an Oscar Martin Scorsese shows us the true story of one of the most controversial Wall Street heroes. Jordan Belfort was golden child of american's finanse world. Quick and stunning success brought him fortune,fame and the feeling of being above the law. Temptations and opportunities were all around and Belfort liked taking them. The most beautiful womens. The most expensive yachts.The most fancy drugs. A crazy party without even a shade of being responsible, followed by unavoidable mistakes and coustant desire to want more and more. Comption, bending law and messing with taxes.Couple more examples of Belfort's master movements.Pumped up and funny, bitter story of a man who always wanted more and eventually got what he deserved. Wolf Dicaprio is a proffesional addict. He belives that all man gotta do is to constantl reach for more, no matter the consequences, but when he falls, he does it in equally spectacular way, under the influence of drugs. The list of drugs that he takes everyday is as long as known to mankind. In Wolf's life dominant things are : money, cocain and sex.
Despite love of his life at his side he keeps on cheating on her with himself : his passion and desperate need to balance on the edge of physical possibility. Dicaprio finally creates a figure,which can present the full of his actor's talent. Though probably he will be skipped during the Oscar gala once again, but his extravergant performance in his movie is worth remembering. Nobody expects happy ending and its abvious that in the final scene we won't see the Wolf standing on elegant yacht with a drink in his hand but the judgment day won't be that terrible.Belfort is indestructible and money still run the world. In my opinion Wolf of Wall Street is genius and grotesque portrait of american greed culture that impress insults, terrifies but also amuses.

The Wolf of Wall Street takes viewers on a fascinating journey from nothing to something to everything and from everything to excess to the end of the run in the life of a man who thrives on his overpowering ego and his endless drive to score the next high, bed the next woman, and pad the bank account. The film decries none of these things, but it does decry them, and anything, really, in excess, and in particular the excess displayed inside the corrupted halls of Stratton Oakmont. The picture thrives on balance, even as it plays up Jordan's excesses almost to a breaking point. The film zooms well past the point of no return early on and will certainly offend many viewers with its unabashed depiction of wealth-induced narcotic, sexual, and verbal indulgence, but within that chaos is a purpose that trumps all of the visual and aural mayhem. It's easily one of the year's finest pictures and a must-see for audiences that can compartmentalize the film's structure and purpose and find the beautiful interconnect between them.
